      26
      Molecular simulation of hydrogen adsorption in graphitic nanofibers
      Cracknell, Roger F.
      Physical Chemistry Chemical Physics (2001), 3 (11), 2091-2097CODEN: PPCPFQ; ISSN:1463-9076. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      The uptake of hydrogen in graphitic nanofibers of 40% by wt. were published. If these results are confirmed, then this class of material could be a suitable storage medium for hydrogen for use in fuel cell vehicles. Results are reported for grand canonical Monte Carlo simulation of hydrogen adsorption in graphitic pores. A classical technique was employed but the results obtained were shown to be consistent with previous path integral Monte Carlo calcns. of Wang and Johnson (Q. Wang and J. K. Johnson, J. Chem. Phys., 1999, 110, 577; Q. Wang and J. K. Johnson, J. Phys. Chem. B, 1999, 103, 277). The interaction between hydrogen and the graphitic surface was modeled initially by dispersion forces. The predicted uptake (up to 1.5%) was much lower than the Baker-Rodriguez results. The results were found to be fairly insensitive as to whether the hydrogen mol. was modeled as a Lennard-Jones sphere or a dumbbell fluid with two Lennard-Jones sites. Two models for a hypothetical potential for chemisorption were also used in the simulation. The potential was based on calcn. of the interaction between at. hydrogen and a graphitic surface. Adsorption of up to 17 wt.% was measured with the stronger model potential but there was negligible desorption at ambient pressure, making it impractical. A more plausible, though still hypothetical, potential gave loadings of up to 8 wt.% in the model system. These results are still much lower than the Baker-Rodriguez data in spite of the fact that there is no evidence to suggest that chemisorption actually occurs in a real system.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3MXjs1yktrY%253D&md5=6bacfc33e17ce59db645d8654923e170

      UFF, a full periodic table force field for molecular mechanics and molecular dynamics simulations
      Rappe, A. K.; Casewit, C. J.; Colwell, K. S.; Goddard, W. A., III; Skiff, W. M.
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (1992), 114 (25), 10024-35CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863.
      A new mol. mechanics force field, the Universal force field (UFF), is described wherein the force field parameters are estd. using general rules based only on the element, its hybridization and its connectivity. The force field functional forms, parameters, and generating formulas for the full periodic table are presented.

    28. 28

      The experimental pattern of Cu-TBA-1 has a few diffraction lines that are unindexed and some that are slightly broadened in comparison with those simulated patterns. This is probably due to the loss of either DMF or EtOH molecules from the lattice or phase change due to grinding while at analysis.

      (a) Zhao, X.; Xiao, B.; Fletcher, A. J.; Thomas, K. M.; Bradshaw, D.; Rosseinsky, M. J. Science 2004, 306, 1012
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      29a
      Hysteretic Adsorption and Desorption of Hydrogen by Nanoporous Metal-Organic Frameworks
      Zhao, Xuebo; Xiao, Bo; Fletcher, Ashleigh J.; Thomas, K. Mark; Bradshaw, Darren; Rosseinsky, Matthew J.
      Science (Washington, DC, United States) (2004), 306 (5698), 1012-1015CODEN: SCIEAS; ISSN:0036-8075. (American Association for the Advancement of Science)
      Adsorption and desorption of hydrogen from nanoporous materials, such as activated C, is usually fully reversible. The authors prepd. nanoporous metal-org. framework materials with flexible linkers in which the pore openings, as characterized in the static structures, appear to be too small to allow H2 to pass. The authors observe hysteresis in their adsorption and desorption kinetics above the supercrit. temp. of H2 that reflects the dynamical opening of the windows between pores. This behavior would allow H2 to be adsorbed at high pressures but stored at lower pressures.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2cXptFyjtbc%253D&md5=42cbb6e1b708cd791929d4e89d328f95
      (b) Panella, B.; Hirscher, M. Adv. Mater. 2005, 17, 538
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      29b
      Hydrogen physisorption in metal-organic porous crystals
      Panella, Barbara; Hirscher, Michael
      Advanced Materials (Weinheim, Germany) (2005), 17 (5), 538-541CODEN: ADVMEW; ISSN:0935-9648. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      Hydrogen adsorption in microporous solid materials may enable H2 to be stored at lower pressures than in compressed-gas tanks, and at higher temps. than for liq. H2. A new class of metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) with a high sp. surface area appears promising for H2 storage. Here, the H2-uptake capacity of MOF-5 over a wide pressure range, at room temp. and at 77 K is investigated. Adsorption of H2 exclusively in the micropores of these metal-org. frameworks is demonstrated.

      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2MXislOhtro%253D&md5=ca320976b7acf59d8d8713f9aec3c50f

      (d) Wegrzyn, J.; Gurevich, M. Appl. Energy. 1996, 55, 71
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      29d
      Adsorbent storage of natural gas
      Wegrzyn, J.; Gurevich, M.
      Applied Energy (1996), 55 (2), 71-83CODEN: APENDX; ISSN:0306-2619. (Elsevier)
      The natural-gas vehicle represents a cost-competitive, lower-emission alternative to the gasoline-fueled vehicle. The immediate challenge that confronts the natural-gas vehicle is extension of its driving range. This paper addresses the question of driving range by reviewing the storage technologies for natural gas. Tech. comparisons are made between storage systems for adsorbent, liquefied and compressed natural gas, and ests. are made of the costs assocd. with refueling with compressed and adsorbent natural gas. We discuss carbon adsorbents, vehicle emissions, designs of storage tanks, cost and safety. For storage-tank system design, we advance the concept that carbon adsorbents, when used with conformable-shaped tanks offer a means of increasing onboard fuel storage and, thereby, the driving range of the vehicle. Lower pressures have the advantages of small refueling costs, the availability of conformable tanks and safety. Our suggested soln. to the driving-range problem of a natural-gas vehicle is the use of improved adsorbents in a low pressure (500 psi) conformable-shaped storage tank.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK2sXit12nt7s%253D&md5=987575140b9e78aa7866a1aa1bc8959e
      (e) Ma, S.; Sun, D.; Simmons, J. M.; Collier, C. D.; Yuan, D.; Zhou, H.-C. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2008, 130, 1012
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      29e
      Metal-Organic Framework from an Anthracene Derivative Containing Nanoscopic Cages Exhibiting High Methane Uptake
      Ma, Shengqian; Sun, Daofeng; Simmons, Jason M.; Collier, Christopher D.; Yuan, Daqiang; Zhou, Hong-Cai
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2008), 130 (3), 1012-1016CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      A microporous metal-org. framework, PCN-14, based on an anthracene deriv., 5,5'- (9,10-anthracene-diyl)di-isophthalate (H4adip), was synthesized under solvothermal reaction conditions. X-ray single crystal anal. revealed that PCN-14 consists of nanoscopic cages suitable for gas storage. N2-adsorption studies of PCN-14 at 77 K reveal a Langmuir surface area of 2176 m2/g and a pore vol. of 0.87 cm3/g. Methane adsorption studies at 290 K and 35 bar show that PCN-14 exhibits an abs. methane-adsorption capacity of 230 vol./vol., 28% higher than the DOE target (180 vol./vol.) for methane storage.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1cXhtlymug%253D%253D&md5=47684d1faab210ef528aa92e5e5754a3
      (f) Rowsell, J. L. C.; Yaghi, O. M. Angew. Chem., Int. Ed. 2005, 44, 4670
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      29f
      Strategies for hydrogen storage in metal-organic frameworks
      Rowsell, Jesse L. C.; Yaghi, Omar M.
      Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2005), 44 (30), 4670-4679CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      A review. Increased attention is being focused on metal-org. frameworks as candidates for hydrogen storage materials. This is a result of their many favorable attributes, such as high porosity, reproducible and facile syntheses, amenability to scale-up, and chem. modification for targeting desired properties. A discussion of several strategies aimed at improving hydrogen uptake in these materials is presented. These strategies include the optimization of pore size and adsorption energy by linker modification, impregnation, catenation, and the inclusion of open metal sites and lighter metals.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2MXnvVSqsrk%253D&md5=a5f3412f19f6b56b433d69a4e36ced31
      (g) Collins, D. J.; Zhou, H.-C. J. Mater. Chem. 2007, 17, 3154
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      29g
      Hydrogen storage in metal-organic frameworks
      Collins, David J.; Zhou, Hong-Cai
      Journal of Materials Chemistry (2007), 17 (30), 3154-3160CODEN: JMACEP; ISSN:0959-9428. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      A review. For any potential hydrogen-storage system, raw uptake capacity must be balanced with the kinetics and thermodn. of uptake and release. Metal-org. frameworks provide unique systems with large overall pore vols. and surface areas, adjustable pore sizes, and tunable framework-adsorbate interaction by ligand functionalization and metal choice. These remarkable materials can potentially fill the niche between other physisorbents such as activated carbon, which have similar uptake at low temps. but low affinity for hydrogen at ambient temp., and chem. sorbents such as hydrides, which have high hydrogen uptakes but undesirable release kinetics and thermodn.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2sXotV2lt7c%253D&md5=211f2f55436d52593c4f7d9b8939bee6
      (h) Sun, D.; Ma, S.; Ke, Y.; Collins, D. J.; Zhou, H.-C. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2006, 128, 3896
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      29h
      An Interweaving MOF with High Hydrogen Uptake
      Sun, Daofeng; Ma, Shengqian; Ke, Yanxiong; Collins, David J.; Zhou, Hong-Cai
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2006), 128 (12), 3896-3897CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      An interweaving Cu metal-org. framework possessing high porosity and high H uptake was successfully designed and synthesized. Cu3(TATB)2(H2O)3 (TATB = 4,4',4"-s-triazine-2,4,6-triyl-tribenzoate) was prepd., its structure detd. and its hydrogen adsorption characteristics also detd.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD28XitVOisLw%253D&md5=115d8b3bf40870866ef6ca6e5e6213b2
      (i) Kondo, M.; Shimamura, M.; Noro, S.-I.; Minakoshi, S.; Asami, A.; Seki, K.; Kitagawa, S. Chem. Mater. 2000, 12, 1288
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      29i
      Microporous Materials Constructed from the Interpenetrated Coordination Networks. Structures and Methane Adsorption Properties
      Kondo, Mitsuru; Shimamura, Mariko; Noro, Shin-ichiro; Minakoshi, Seika; Asami, Akiko; Seki, Kenji; Kitagawa, Susumu
      Chemistry of Materials (2000), 12 (5), 1288-1299CODEN: CMATEX; ISSN:0897-4756. (American Chemical Society)
      Five new coordination compds. with 4,4'-azopyridine (azpy), [Mn(azpy)(NO3)2(H2O)2]·2EtOH (1·2EtOH), [Co2(azpy)3(NO3)4]·Me2CO·3H2O (2·Me2CO·3H2O), [Co(azpy)2(NCS)2]·0.5EtOH (3·0.5EtOH), [Cd(azpy)2(NO3)2]·(azpy) (4·azpy), and [Cd2(azpy)3(NO3)4]·2Me2CO (5·2Me2CO), were synthesized and structurally characterized. The reaction of Mn(NO3)2·6H2O with azpy in EtOH/acetone affords 1·2EtOH, whose network consists of 1-dimensional chains of [Mn(azpy)(H2O)2]n. The chains are assocd. by H bonding to provide a logcabin-type three-dimensional structure, which creates ∼8 × 8 Å of channels, filled with EtOH mols. The treatment of Co(NO3)2·6H2O and Co(NCS)2·4H2O with azpy produces 2·Me2CO·3H2O and 3·0.5EtOH, resp., which have a brick-wall and a rhombus-type two-dimensional networks. The reaction of Cd(NO3)2·4H2O with azpy affords 4·azpy from the EtOH/H2O media, while the reaction in the EtOH/acetone media provides 5·2Me2CO. 4·Azpy and 5·2Me2CO form a square-grid- and a herringbone-type two-dimensional networks, resp. The two-dimensional sheets of 4·azpy stack without interpenetration, leading to large size of channels, which are filled with free azpy mols. The two-dimensional networks of 2·Me2CO·3H2O, 3·0.5EtOH, and 5·2Me2CO are quadruply, doubly, and triply interpenetrated, resp. Despite the interpenetration, their networks create the microporous channels filled with guest solvent mols. The dried compds. 2, 3, and 5 adsorb methane between 1 and 36 atm at 25°, in which 3 and 5 exhibit Langmuir-type isotherms. The inherent micropore vols. for 3 and 5 are 0.685 and 3.30 mmol/g, resp. XRPD measurements under reduced pressure at 100° reveal that the channel structure of 3 is the most stable in these compds.; the obsd. XRPD pattern is in good agreement with that of the simulated pattern of the single-crystal model. Compds. 2 and 5 also retain the porous structures, however, their pore structures are distorted upon loss of guest included mols.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3cXit1agtbo%253D&md5=bb6783e8d94fa4d01cb7051890954647
      (j) Bourrelly, S.; Llewellyn, P. L.; Serre, C.; Millange, F.; Loiseau, T.; Ferey, G. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2005, 127, 13519
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      29j
      Different Adsorption Behaviors of Methane and Carbon Dioxide in the Isotypic Nanoporous Metal Terephthalates MIL-53 and MIL-47
      Bourrelly, Sandrine; Llewellyn, Philip L.; Serre, Christian; Millange, Franck; Loiseau, Thierry; Ferey, Gerard
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2005), 127 (39), 13519-13521CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      A distinct step in the isotherm occurs during the adsorption of CO2 on MIL-53 at 304 K. Such behavior is neither obsd. during the adsorption of CH4 on MIL-53 nor during the adsorption on the isostructural MIL-47. This phenomenon seems to be due to a different mechanism than that of previous adsorption steps on MOF samples. It is suggested that a breathing behavior is induced in MIL-53 during CO2 adsorption.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2MXpvFSnu70%253D&md5=e3d0228e57af031b6019deeeffa6d575
      (k) Dueren, T.; Sarkisov, L.; Yaghi, O. M.; Snurr, R. Q. Langmuir 2004, 20, 2683
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      29k
      Design of New Materials for Methane Storage
      Dueren, Tina; Sarkisov, Lev; Yaghi, Omar M.; Snurr, Randall Q.
      Langmuir (2004), 20 (7), 2683-2689CODEN: LANGD5; ISSN:0743-7463. (American Chemical Society)
      One of the strategic goals of the modern automobile manufg. industry is to replace gasoline and diesel with alternative fuels such as natural gas. In this report, we elucidate the desired characteristics of an optimal adsorbent for gas storage. The U.S. Department of Energy has outlined several requirements that adsorbents must fulfill for natural gas to become economically viable, with a key criterion being the amt. adsorbed at 35 bar. We explore the adsorption characteristics of novel metal-org. materials (IRMOFs and mol. squares) and contrast them with the characteristics of two zeolites, MCM-41, and different carbon nanotubes. Using mol. simulations, we uncover the complex interplay of the factors influencing methane adsorption, esp. the surface area, the capacity or free vol., the strength of the energetic interaction, and the pore size distribution. We also explain the extraordinary adsorption properties of IRMOF materials and propose new, not yet synthesized IRMOF structures with adsorption characteristics that are predicted to exceed the best exptl. results to date by up to 36%.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2cXhs1yju70%253D&md5=b58bdcd29d208b0d424b6427980189f4
    30. 30
      (a) Park, K. S.; Ni, Z.; Cote, A. P.; Choi, J. Y.; Huang, R. D.; Uribe-Romo, F. J.; Chae, H. K.; O’Keeffe, M.; Yaghi, O. M. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A 2006, 103, 10186
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      30a
      Exceptional chemical and thermal stability of zeolitic imidazolate frameworks
      Park, Kyo Sung; Ni, Zheng; Cote, Adrien P.; Choi, Jae Yong; Huang, Rudan; Uribe-Romo, Fernando J.; Chae, Hee K.; O'Keeffe, Michael; Yaghi, Omar M.
      Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America (2006), 103 (27), 10186-10191CODEN: PNASA6; ISSN:0027-8424. (National Academy of Sciences)
      Twelve zeolitic imidazolate frameworks (ZIFs; termed ZIF-1 to -12) were synthesized as crystals by copolymn. of either Zn(II) (ZIF-1 to -4, -6 to -8, and -10 to -11) or Co(II) (ZIF-9 and -12) with imidazolate-type links. The ZIF crystal structures are based on the nets of seven distinct aluminosilicate zeolites: tetrahedral Si(Al) and the bridging O are replaced with transition metal ion and imidazolate link, resp. One example of mixed-coordination imidazolate of Zn(II) and In(III) (ZIF-5) based on the garnet net is reported. Study of the gas adsorption and thermal and chem. stability of two prototypical members, ZIF-8 and -11, demonstrated their permanent porosity (Langmuir surface area = 1,810 m2/g), high thermal stability (up to 550°), and remarkable chem. resistance to boiling alk. H2O and org. solvents.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD28XntlKjtbo%253D&md5=c28cd5862d4765fe4e4937195f5bb4df
      (b) Zhou, W.; Wu, H.; Hartman, M. R.; Yildirim, T. J. Phys. Chem. C 2007, 111, 16131
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      30b
      Hydrogen and Methane Adsorption in Metal-Organic Frameworks: A High-Pressure Volumetric Study
      Zhou, Wei; Wu, Hui; Hartman, Michael R.; Yildirim, Taner
      Journal of Physical Chemistry C (2007), 111 (44), 16131-16137CODEN: JPCCCK; ISSN:1932-7447. (American Chemical Society)
      The authors report hydrogen and methane adsorption isotherms in 2 prototypical metal-org. framework compds. (i.e., MOF5 and ZIF8) over a large temp. (30-300 K) and pressure (up to 65 bar) range using a fully computer-controlled Sieverts app. In a volumetric method, a proper choice of real gas equation of state is crit. for obtaining reliable isotherm data. The widely used van der Waals equation of state (EOS) is not adequate to describe H2 and CH4, while the modified Benedict-Webb-Rubin (MBWR) EOS works well, even at very low temps. and high pressures. With the known sample mass and bulk d., the skeleton d. and the specific pore vol. of MOF5 and ZIF8 were also measured. In addn. to excess and abs. adsorption isotherms, the authors also introduce an effective adsorption which compares the amts. of gas adsorbed in a container with and without the adsorbent. At low temps., the maximal excess adsorption capacities of H2 and CH4 in MOF5 are 10.3% and 51.7%, resp., while they are only 4.4% and 22.4% in ZIF8. From the temp.-dependent isotherm data, the isosteric heat of adsorption (Qst) was also estd. The excess Qst's for the initial H2 and CH4 adsorption in MOF5 are ∼4.8 kJ/mol and ∼12.2 kJ/mol, resp. The authors obtained similar Qst's for ZIF8. The authors hope that the detailed isotherm curves reported here over a large temp. and pressure range will be a crit. test for future grand canonical Monte Carlo simulations and force-field models.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2sXhtFWqtbjL&md5=5929450c7b34ee817bcb88a1d1461a5b
      (c) Chen, B. L.; Ma, S. Q.; Hurtado, E. J.; Lobkovsky, E. B.; Zhou, H. C. Inorg. Chem. 2007, 46, 8490
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      30c
      A triply interpenetrated microporous metal-organic framework for selective sorption of gas molecules
      Chen, Banglin; Ma, Shengqian; Hurtado, Eric J.; Lobkovsky, Emil B.; Zhou, Hong-Cai
      Inorganic Chemistry (2007), 46 (21), 8490-8492CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
      A microporous metal-org. framework Zn(ADC)(4,4'-Bpe)0.5.xG [1; ADC = 4,4'-azobenzenedicarboxylate, 4,4'-Bpe = trans-bis(4-pyridyl)ethylene, G = 2.5DMF.0.5H2O] with a triply interpenetrative primitive cubic net was synthesized and characterized. With pores of ∼3.4 × 3.4 Å, the activated 1a (no solvent) exhibits highly selective sorption behavior toward H2/N2, H2/CO, and CO2/CH4.
      >> More from SciFinder ®

      30d
      A microporous metal-organic framework for gas-chromatographic separation of alkanes
      Chen, Banglin; Liang, Chengdu; Yang, Jun; Contreras, Damacio S.; Clancy, Yvette L.; Lobkovsky, Emil B.; Yaghi, Omar M.; Dai, Sheng
      Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2006), 45 (9), 1390-1393CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      Filling the pores: A zinc-based metal-org. framework (MOF) can be transformed reversibly from an open (a) to a dense (b) configuration. The microporous solid is the 1st example of a MOF that is highly selective in the gas-chromatog. sepn. of alkanes.

      30e
      Exceptional H2 Saturation Uptake in Microporous Metal-Organic Frameworks
      Wong-Foy, Antek G.; Matzger, Adam J.; Yaghi, Omar M.
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2006), 128 (11), 3494-3495CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      Satn. H2 uptake in a series of microporous metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) has been measured at 77 K. Satn. pressures vary between 25 and 80 bar across the series, with MOF-177 showing the highest uptake on a gravimetric basis (7.5 wt %) and IRMOF-20 showing the highest uptake on a volumetric basis at 34 g/L. These results demonstrate that max. H2 storage capacity in MOFs correlates well to surface area, and that feasible volumetric uptakes can be realized even in highly porous materials.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD28XhvVCjsr8%253D&md5=f6d94bff4ebfd39eedeec1e04573a2e4
      (f) Rowsell, J. L. C.; Yaghi, O. M. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2006, 128, 1304
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      30f
      Effects of Functionalization, Catenation, and Variation of the Metal Oxide and Organic Linking Units on the Low-Pressure Hydrogen Adsorption Properties of Metal-Organic Frameworks
      Rowsell, Jesse L. C.; Yaghi, Omar M.
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2006), 128 (4), 1304-1315CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      The dihydrogen adsorption isotherms of eight metal-org. frameworks (MOFs), measured at 77 K up to a pressure of 1 atm, were examd. for correlations with their structural features. All materials display approx. Type I isotherms with no hysteresis, and satn. was not reached for any of the materials under these conditions. Among the six iso-reticular MOFs (IRMOFs) studied, the catenated materials exhibit the largest capacities on a molar basis, up to 9.8 H2 per formula unit. The addn. of functional groups (-Br, -NH2, -C2H4-) to the phenylene links of IRMOF-1 (MOF-5), or their replacement with thieno[3,2-b]thiophene moieties in IRMOF-20, altered the adsorption behavior by a minor amt. despite large variations in the pore vols. of the resulting materials. But replacement of the metal oxide units with those contg. coordinatively unsatd. metal sites resulted in greater H2 uptake. The enhanced affinities of these materials, MOF-74 and HKUST-1, were further demonstrated by calcn. of the isosteric heats of adsorption, which were larger across much of the range of coverage examd., compared to those of representative IRMOFs. Probably under low-loading conditions, the H2 adsorption behavior of MOFs can be improved by imparting larger charge gradients on the metal oxide units and adjusting the link metrics to constrict the pore dimensions; however, a large pore vol. is still a prerequisite feature.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD28XitV2msg%253D%253D&md5=76a0797beec956e59ca2ddf029f5a386
      (g) Dailly, A.; Vajo, J. J.; Ahn, C. C. J. Phys. Chem. B 2006, 110, 1099
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      30g
      Saturation of Hydrogen Sorption in Zn Benzenedicarboxylate and Zn Naphthalenedicarboxylate
      Dailly, Anne; Vajo, John J.; Ahn, Channing C.
      Journal of Physical Chemistry B (2006), 110 (3), 1099-1101CODEN: JPCBFK; ISSN:1520-6106. (American Chemical Society)
      We report excess hydrogen satn. values from high-pressure isotherms of metal org. framework structures taken at 77 K. Zn benzendicarboxylate (IRMOF-1) and Zn naphthalendicarboxylate (IRMOF-8) linker structures show identical satn. values of 137 hydrogen mols. on a per unit cell basis, despite the higher sorption potential of IRMOF-8 of 6.1 kJ/mol over that of IRMOF-1 of 4.1kJ/mol. Charge transfer between linker and vertex, as well as surface area, appear to dominate the sorption behavior, over that of linker length in these two systems.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD28XlsFKn&md5=583b832915589b03e1ce7de5f08fba5b
      (h) Zhao, D.; Yuan, D.; Zhou, H.-C. Energy Environ. Sci. 2008, 1, 222
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      30h
      The current status of hydrogen storage in metal-organic frameworks
      Zhao, Dan; Yuan, Daqiang; Zhou, Hong-Cai
      Energy & Environmental Science (2008), 1 (2), 222-235CODEN: EESNBY; ISSN:1754-5706. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      A review. The theor. and exptl. hydrogen storage studies on metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) have been reviewed. Seven distinct factors influencing hydrogen uptake capacity in MOFs have been classified and discussed. Based on existing studies, some possible future developments have been proposed.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1cXht1amu7%252FM&md5=8cf417a3e457630ab942022a26fc780e
    31. 31

      We replaced the 2-F-4-TBA with 3-F-4-TBA, which is the 3-substituted fluorinated analogue of 4-TBA. The reaction of 3-F-4-TBA with Cu(NO3)2 was resulted into the formation of plate like blue crystals similar to Cu-TBA-2 and Cu-TBA-2F. But in this case, we are unable to grow proper sized crystals for single crystal X-ray diffraction studies after several attempts. The formation of same phase like Cu-TBA-2 and Cu-TBA-2F was confirmed by PXRD studies in the case of Cu-TBA-3F (see Supporting Information, Figure S4).

      There is no corresponding record for this reference.

      This article references 31 other publications.

      1. 1
        (a) Janiak, C. J. Chem. Soc., Dalton Trans. 2003, 2781
        [Crossref], Google Scholar

        (b) Moulton, B.; Zaworotko, M. J. Chem. Rev. 2001, 101, 1629
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        1b
        From molecules to crystal engineering. Supramolecular isomerism and polymorphism in network solids
        Moulton, Brian; Zaworotko, Michael J.
        Chemical Reviews (Washington, D. C.) (2001), 101 (6), 1629-1658CODEN: CHREAY; ISSN:0009-2665. (American Chemical Society)
        A review with 299 refs. on how the advances in supramol. chem. have impacted the manner in which chemists view the existence of single crystals and the design of new cryst. phases. Coordination polymers, H-bonded networks, and supramol. isomerism and polymorphism are considered.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3MXjtlyqtrg%253D&md5=00fbfe863055d07d1773be77dc52f023
        (c) Eddaoudi, M.; Moler, D. B.; Li, H.; Chen, B.; Reineke, T. M.; O’Keeffe, M.; Yaghi, O. M. Acc. Chem. Res. 2001, 34, 319
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        1c
        Modular Chemistry: Secondary Building Units as a Basis for the Design of Highly Porous and Robust Metal-Organic Carboxylate Frameworks
        Eddaoudi, Mohamed; Moler, David B.; Li, Hailian; Chen, Banglin; Reineke, Theresa M.; O'Keeffe, Michael; Yaghi, Omar M.
        Accounts of Chemical Research (2001), 34 (4), 319-330CODEN: ACHRE4; ISSN:0001-4842. (American Chemical Society)
        A review, with 38 refs. Secondary building units (SBUs) are mol. complexes and cluster entities in which ligand coordination modes and metal coordination environments can be used in the transformation of these fragments into extended porous networks using polytopic linkers (1,4-benzenedicarboxylate, 1,3,5,7-adamantanetetracarboxylate, etc.). Consideration of the geometric and chem. attributes of the SBUs and linkers leads to prediction of the framework topol., and in turn to the design and synthesis of a new class of porous materials with robust structures and high porosity.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3MXhtFymsL0%253D&md5=e3df2f7492090aee280676f044e3b7af
        (d) Robson, R. J. Chem. Soc., Dalton Trans. 2000, 3735
        [Crossref], Google Scholar
        There is no corresponding record for this reference.
        (e) Yaghi, O. M. Nat. Mater. 2007, 6, 92
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        1e
        Metal-organic Frameworks: A tale of two entanglements
        Yaghi, Omar M.
        Nature Materials (2007), 6 (2), 92-93CODEN: NMAACR; ISSN:1476-1122. (Nature Publishing Group)
        A review. Entanglement of interpenetrating metal-org. frameworks has been considered a drawback to porosity. However, the pore size of these structures can be controlled through framework dynamics to achieve selectivity and increased binding of ions and gases.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2sXhtFyhsr4%253D&md5=9fe3b61b10a7a75dfa647d0cf59f7d60
        (f) Georgiev, I. G.; MacGillivray, L. R. Chem. Soc. Rev. 2007, 36, 1239
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        1f
        Metal-mediated reactivity in the organic solid state: From self-assembled complexes to metal-organic frameworks
        Georgiev, Ivan G.; MacGillivray, Leonard R.
        Chemical Society Reviews (2007), 36 (8), 1239-1248CODEN: CSRVBR; ISSN:0306-0012. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        A review. The purpose of this tutorial review is to address the use of metal ions to mediate reactions in the org. solid state. We describe metal complexes and coordination networks that facilitate dimerizations, oligomerizations and polymns. of olefins and acetylenes via irradn. (e.g. UV and 60Co γ-rays) and thermal annealing. We show how metal ions can be utilized to direct the formation of polymers and mols. We also describe how supramol. chem. has recently influenced dimerization processes in self-assembled metal-org. solids.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2sXnsVChurs%253D&md5=f705e80c302094615508c418acd14a64
        (g) Corma, A.; Garcia, H.; Xamena, F. X. L. Chem. Rev. 2010, 110, 4606
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        1g
        Engineering Metal Organic Frameworks for Heterogeneous Catalysis
        Corma, A.; Garcia, H.; Llabres i Xamena, F. X.
        Chemical Reviews (Washington, DC, United States) (2010), 110 (8), 4606-4655CODEN: CHREAY; ISSN:0009-2665. (American Chemical Society)
        A review, including the design of MOFs for catalysis and evaluation of its potential as catalyst as well as catalysis by MOFs with active metal sites, with reactive functional groups, and MOFs as host matrixes or nanometric reaction cavities.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXktFers7Y%253D&md5=ce714f3d4475f4ac2a3d81b13931ccc3
        (h) James, S. L. Chem. Soc. Rev. 2003, 32, 276
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        1h
        Metal-organic frameworks
        James, Stuart L.
        Chemical Society Reviews (2003), 32 (5), 276-288CODEN: CSRVBR; ISSN:0306-0012. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        A review. Metal-org. frameworks are a recently-identified class of porous polymeric material, consisting of metal ions linked together by org. bridging ligands, and are a new development on the interface between mol. coordination chem. and materials science. A range of novel structures was prepd. which feature amongst the largest pores known for cryst. compds., very high sorption capacities and complex sorption behavior not seen in aluminosilicate zeolites. The development of synthetic approaches to these materials and studies of their properties are reviewed.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3sXmtFOltLY%253D&md5=e9e83de0580c0b7dc9929ea3594efe12
        (i) Yaghi, O. M.; Li, H.; Davis, C.; Richardson, D.; Groy, T. L. Acc. Chem. Res. 1998, 31, 474
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        1i
        Synthetic Strategies, Structure Patterns, and Emerging Properties in the Chemistry of Modular Porous Solids
        Yaghi, Omar M.; Li, Hailian; Davis, Charles; Richardson, David; Groy, Thomas L.
        Accounts of Chemical Research (1998), 31 (8), 474-484CODEN: ACHRE4; ISSN:0001-4842. (American Chemical Society)
        A review with 23 refs. The authors have established a program aimed at constructing porous networks by linking inorg. metal sulfide clusters and org. mols. with transition metal ions. This program is designed to define and investigate the parameters contributing to the assembly of materials from mol. building blocks. Specifically this review outlines (i)various synthetic strategies developed for producing porous modular networks in cryst. form using diffusion, solvothermal, and gel crystal growth techniques, (ii)methods of achieving rigid noninterpenetrated and truly porous modular frameworks capable of reversible binding and removal of guests without affecting the structural integrity of the host framework, and (iii)emerging novel properties and prospective applications resulting from tailoring the mol. building blocks and the metal ion centers of the host structure.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK1cXltFKkt70%253D&md5=20be179fc9b8b3ea42ec714e744bc803
        (j) Janiak, C. Angew. Chem., Int. Ed. Engl. 1997, 36, 1431
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        1j
        Functional organic analogs of zeolites based on metal-organic coordination frameworks
        Janiak, Christoph
        Angewandte Chemie, International Edition in English (1997), 36 (13/14), 1431-1434CODEN: ACIEAY; ISSN:0570-0833. (Wiley-VCH)
        A review, with ∼25 refs., is given on zeolite analogs based on metal-org. frameworks.
        >> More from SciFinder ®

        (k) Blake, A. J.; Champness, N. R.; Hubberstey, P.; Li, W.-S.; Withersby, M. A.; Schroder, M. Coord. Chem. Rev. 1999, 183, 117
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        1k
        Inorganic crystal engineering using self-assembly of tailored building-blocks
        Blake, Alexander J.; Champness, Neil R.; Hubberstey, Peter; Li, Wan-Sheung; Withersby, Matthew A.; Schroder, Martin
        Coordination Chemistry Reviews (1999), 183 (), 117-138CODEN: CCHRAM; ISSN:0010-8545. (Elsevier Science S.A.)
        The use of transition metal complexes of bridging bidentate ligands to construct predictable, multi-dimensional infinite networks is an area of chem. which has received ever-increasing attention over recent years. This article will review with 36 refs. the advances that were made in this field of research and will illustrate how ligand design and the properties of the transition metal and counteranion can be used to control network geometry and thus crystal structure. The range of network topologies and structural motifs that were constructed thus far will be outlined with particular emphasis upon how specific arrays can be prepd. via rational design of mol. building-blocks. The unusual phenomenon of interpenetration, or polycatenation, is discussed and methods to achieve control over this effect will be highlighted.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK1MXhslarsr0%253D&md5=b8da3e19a9240ee5133faa9936910de6
        (l) Kesanli, B.; Cui, Y.; Smith, M.; Bittner, E.; Bockrath, B.; Lin, W. Angew. Chem., Int. Ed. 2005, 44, 72
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        1l
        Highly interpenetrated metal-organic frameworks for hydrogen storage
        Kesanli, Banu; Cui, Yong; Smith, Milton R.; Bittner, Edward W.; Brockrath, Bradley C.; Lin, Wenbin
        Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2005), 44 (1), 72-75CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        Highly interpenetrating metal-org. frameworks were synthesized from zinc salts (i.e., Zn(ClO4)2 or ZnI2) and arom.-rich dicarboxylic acids (i.e., 6,6'-dichloro-2,2'-diethoxy-1,1'-binaphthyl-4,4'-dibenzoic acid (I) and 6,6'-dichloro-2,2'-dibenzyloxy-1,1'-binaphthyl-4,4-dibenzoic acid (II)), to form cryst. materials of general structures [Zn4(μ4-O)(I)3(DMF)2].4DMF.3MeOH.2H2O and [Zn4(μ4-O)(II)3].5DMF.5EtOH.H2O. These materials, with single-crystal x-ray diffraction patterns that suggest a fourfold three-dimensional interpenetrating networks, have hydrogen uptakes comparable to those of the best carbon nanotubes. The mechanism of hydrogen uptake seems to be favored by the proximity of arom. rings.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2MXptVKl&md5=6bb093dc5a591d84717f1980be320438
      2. 2

        The DOE targets for the gravimetric and volumetric system for near-ambient temperature (from −40 to 85 °C) and moderate pressure (less than 100 bar) are 6.0 wt % (45 g/L) for the year 2010 and 9.0 wt % (81 g/L) for 2015.

      3. 3
        (a) Dillon, A. C.; Jones, K. M.; Bekkedahl, T. A.; Kiang, C. H.; Bethune, D. S.; Heben, M. J. Nature 1997, 386, 377
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        3a
        Storage of hydrogen in single-walled carbon nanotubes
        Dillon, A. C.; Jones, K. M.; Bekkedahl, T. A.; Kiang, C. H.; Bethune, D. S.; Heben, M. J.
        Nature (London) (1997), 386 (6623), 377-379CODEN: NATUAS; ISSN:0028-0836. (Macmillan Magazines)
        The authors show that hydrogen can condense to high d. inside narrow, single-walled nanotubes (SWNTs). Temp.-programmed desorption spectroscopy shows that hydrogen will condense inside SWNTs under conditions that do not induce adsorption within a std. mesoporous activated carbon. The very high hydrogen uptake in these materials suggests that they might be effective as a hydrogen storage material for fuel-cell elec. vehicles.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK2sXit1Wmu74%253D&md5=aae25af539f9f3121028e547f0ff116a
        (b) Liu, C.; Fan, Y. Y.; Liu, M.; Cong, H. T.; Cheng, H. M.; Dresselhaus, M. S. Science 1999, 286, 1127
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        3b
        Hydrogen storage in single-walled carbon nanotubes at room temperature
        Liu, C.; Fan, Y. Y.; Liu, M.; Cong, H. T.; Cheng, H. M.; Dresselhaus, M. S.
        Science (Washington, D. C.) (1999), 286 (5442), 1127-1129CODEN: SCIEAS; ISSN:0036-8075. (American Association for the Advancement of Science)
        Masses of single-walled C nanotubes (SWNTs) with a large mean diam. of ∼1.85 nm, synthesized by a semicontinuous hydrogen arc discharge method, were employed for hydrogen adsorption expts. in their as-prepd. and pretreated states. A hydrogen storage capacity of 4.2 wt. percent, or a hydrogen to C atom ratio of 0.52, was achieved reproducibly at room temp. under a modestly high pressure (∼10 megapascal) for a SWNT sample of ∼500 mg wt. that was soaked in HCl and then heat-treated in vacuum. Also, 78.3% of the adsorbed hydrogen (3.3 wt. percent) could be released under ambient pressure at room temp., while the release of the residual stored hydrogen (0.9 wt. percent) required some heating of the sample. Because the SWNTs can be easily produced and show reproducible and modestly high hydrogen uptake at room temp., they show promise as an effective hydrogen storage material.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK1MXnt1Kltrw%253D&md5=abbc3ed16c33d809b06eba8b5bd16955
        (c) Chambers, A.; Park, C.; Baker, R. T. K.; Rodriguez, N. M. J. Phys. Chem. B 1998, 102, 4253
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        3c
        Hydrogen Storage in Graphite Nanofibers
        Chambers, Alan; Park, Colin; Baker, R. Terry K.; Rodriguez, Nelly M.
        Journal of Physical Chemistry B (1998), 102 (22), 4253-4256CODEN: JPCBFK; ISSN:1089-5647. (American Chemical Society)
        Graphite nanofibers are a novel material that is produced from the dissocn. of carbon-contg. gases over selected metal surfaces. The solid consists of very small graphite platelets, 30-500 Å in width, which are stacked in a perfectly arranged conformation. The material is capable of sorbing and retaining in excess of 20 L (STP) of hydrogen per g of carbon when the nanofibers are exposed to the gas at pressures of 120 atm at 25°, a value that is over an order of magnitude higher than that found with conventional hydrogen storage systems. This behavior is rationalized in terms of the unique cryst. arrangement existing within the graphite nanofiber structure, where the platelets generate a system comprised entirely of slit-shaped nanopores, in which only edge sites are exposed. Since the interplanar distance within the material is 3.37 Å, sorption of mol. hydrogen, which possesses a kinetic diam. of 2.89 Å, is a facile process owing to the short diffusion path. In addn., owing to the weak (van der Waals) bonding of the platelets, these nonrigid wall nanopores can expand to accommodate hydrogen in a multilayer configuration. Subsequent lowering of the pressure to nearly atm. conditions results in the release of a major fraction of the stored hydrogen at room temp.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK1cXivVaqsrc%253D&md5=dc1bc9aee477a84739154d42234093df
        (d) Chen, P.; Wu, X.; Lin, J.; Tan, K. L. Science 1999, 285, 91
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        3d
        High H2 uptake by alkali-doped carbon nanotubes under ambient pressure and moderate temperatures
        Chen, P.; Wu, X.; Lin, J.; Tan, K. L.
        Science (Washington, D. C.) (1999), 285 (5424), 91-93CODEN: SCIEAS; ISSN:0036-8075. (American Association for the Advancement of Science)
        Lithium- or potassium-doped carbon nanotubes can absorb ∼20 or ∼14% of hydrogen at moderate (200° to 400°C) or room temps., resp., under ambient pressure. These values are greater than those of metal hydride and cryoadsorption systems. The hydrogen stored in the lithium- or potassium-doped carbon nanotubes can be released at higher temps., and the sorption-desorption cycle can be repeated with little decrease in the sorption capacity. The high hydrogen-uptake capacity of these systems may be derived from the special open-edged, layered structure of the carbon nanotubes made from methane, as well as the catalytic effect of alkali metals.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK1MXksVCqsLY%253D&md5=f5bba3e630625155994c8fd3b55c36ca
        (e) Huang, T. Nanotechnology That Will Change the World; Enlighten Noah Publishing: 2002, p 38.
        Google Scholar
        There is no corresponding record for this reference.
      4. 4
        (a) Li, Y.; Yang, R. T. J. Phys. Chem. B 2006, 110, 17175
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        4a
        Hydrogen Storage in Low Silica Type X Zeolites
        Li, Yingwei; Yang, Ralph T.
        Journal of Physical Chemistry B (2006), 110 (34), 17175-17181CODEN: JPCBFK; ISSN:1520-6106. (American Chemical Society)
        Low silica type X zeolites (LSX, Si/Al = 1) fully exchanged by alkali-metal cations (Li+, Na+, and K+) were studied for their hydrogen storage capacities. Hydrogen adsorption isotherms were measured sep. at 77 K and <1 atm, and at 298 K and <10 MPa. It was found that the hydrogen adsorption capacity of LSX zeolite depended strongly on the cationic radius and the d. of the cations that are located on the exposed sites. The interaction energies between H2 and the cations follow the order Li+ > Na+ > K+, as predicted based on the ionic radii. Oxygen anions on zeolite framework were minor adsorption sites. Li-LSX had an H2 capacity of 1.5 wt % at 77 K and 1 atm, and a capacity of 0.6 wt % at 298 K and 10 MPa, among the highest of known sorbents. The hydrogen capacity in LSX zeolite by bridged hydrogen spillover was also investigated. A simple and effective technique was employed to build carbon bridges between the H2 dissocn. catalyst and the zeolite to facilitate spillover of hydrogen atoms. Thus, the hydrogen storage capacity of Li-LSX zeolite was enhanced to 1.6 wt % (by a factor of 2.6) at 298 K and 10 MPa. This is by far the highest hydrogen storage capacity obtained on a zeolite material at room temp. Furthermore, the adsorption rates were fast, and the storages were shown to be fully reversible and rechargeable. Further optimization of the bridge building technique would lead to an addnl. enhancement of hydrogen storage.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD28XnvVKiurs%253D&md5=49e74627bfcc33946173b2d9696f9cf3
        (b) Nijkamp, M. G.; Raaymakers, J. E.; van Dillen, A. J.; de Jong, K. P. Appl. Phys. A: Mater. Sci. Process. 2001, 72, 619
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        4b
        Hydrogen storage by using physisorption materials demands
        Nijkamp, M. G.; Raaymakers, J. E. M. J.; Van Dillen, A. J.; De Jong, K. P.
        Applied Physics A: Materials Science & Processing (2001), 72 (5), 619-623CODEN: APAMFC; ISSN:0947-8396. (Springer-Verlag)
        A survey is presented of the storage capacities of a large no. of different adsorbents for hydrogen at 77 K and 1 bar. Results are evaluated to examine the feasibility and perspectives of transportable and reversible storage systems based on physisorption of hydrogen on adsorbents. Microporous adsorbents, e.g. zeolites and activated carbons, display appreciable sorption capacities. Based on their micropore vol. (∼ 1 mL/g) carbon-based sorbents display the largest adsorption, viz. 238 mL (STP)/g, at the prevailing conditions. Optimization of sorbent and adsorption conditions is expected to lead to adsorption of ∼ 560 mL (STP)/g, close to targets set for mobile applications.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3MXjvFGjtb0%253D&md5=b56f58274ba1aca00970c282ebccc38f
        (c) Darkrim, F.; Aoufi, A.; Malbrunot, P.; Levesque, D. J. Chem. Phys. 2000, 112, 5991
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        4c
        Hydrogen adsorption in the NaA zeolite. A comparison between numerical simulations and experiments
        Darkrim, Farida; Aoufi, Asdin; Malbrunot, Pierre; Levesque, Dominique
        Journal of Chemical Physics (2000), 112 (13), 5991-5999CODEN: JCPSA6; ISSN:0021-9606. (American Institute of Physics)
        At room temp. and high pressures between 10 MPa and 140 MPa, H adsorption in the NaA zeolite was studied by grand canonical Monte Carlo simulation. The computed values of the av. no. of H mols. adsorbed in a crystal unit were compared to those measured at the same temp. and pressures between 10-70 MPa. A quant. agreement between the 2 sets of values was obtained by, in the simulations, a model of zeolite crystal where the Al, Si, O, and Na atoms, disposed in accordance with the crystallog. structure of the NaA zeolite detd. by x-ray diffraction, had effective elec. charges and were sources of a van der Waals interaction. The adsorption of H mols. in the NaA zeolite resulted from the combined effects of van der Waals interactions and polarization of hydrogen mols. induced by the elec. field of the effective charges.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3cXhsl2itL4%253D&md5=986888f59149a173587d18a255170d59

      5. 5
        (a) Hynek, S.; Fuller, W.; Bentley, J. Int. J. Hydrogen Energy 1997, 22, 601
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        5a
        Hydrogen storage by carbon sorption
        Hynek, Scott; Fuller, Ware; Bentley, Jeffrey
        International Journal of Hydrogen Energy (1997), 22 (6), 601-610CODEN: IJHEDX; ISSN:0360-3199. (Elsevier)
        This research detd. exptl. the extent to which carbon sorbents such as activated carbon, carbon black, carbon aerogels, and carbon mol. sieves can augment the capacity of compressed hydrogen gas (CHG) storage systems. These carbon sorbents were tested at ambient temp. (300 K), at acetone-and-dry-ice temp. (190 K), and at liq.-nitrogen temp. (80 K). We concluded that, at the pressures typical of vehicular CHG storage systems (200 bar), only one of the ten carbon sorbents tested could augment the capacity of CHG storage vessels. This improvement was marginal at 190 K and 300 K, and non-existent at 80 K.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK2sXlt1CgsLg%253D&md5=af5925b3a4308ed894d56c799a032a3c
        (b) Carpetis, C.; Peschka, W. Int. J. Hydrogen Energy 1980, 5, 539
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        5b
        A study of hydrogen storage by use of cryoadsorbents
        Carpetis, C.; Peschka, W.
        International Journal of Hydrogen Energy (1980), 5 (5), 539-54CODEN: IJHEDX; ISSN:0360-3199.
        Investigations on the techniques and economics of H storage by cryoadsorption are reported. Also, a comparison with alternative storage methods is included. The H-storage capacity of several adsorbents at 65-150 K was investigated exptl. Based on these data, economics and operating conditions for min. total costs of the system are calcd. Utilization-factor and capacity-factor parameters are decisive for outlining the favorable ranges of application for competitive H storage methods.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaL3MXhsValur4%253D&md5=d1187c6f7890c416cb21336df279a39b
        (c) Noh, J. S.; Agarwal, R. K.; Schwarz, J. A. Int. J. Hydrogen Energy 1987, 12, 693
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        5c
        Hydrogen storage systems using activated carbon
        Noh, J. S.; Agarwal, R. K.; Schwarz, J. A.
        International Journal of Hydrogen Energy (1987), 12 (10), 693-700CODEN: IJHEDX; ISSN:0360-3199.
        A concept called Modification/Metal Assisted Cold Storage (MACS) is described. This includes the improvement of the efficiency of activated carbons in two ways: one is modification of the acidity of the activated-C surfaces and the other is modification by metal impregnation of the activated-C surface. Evaluation of the system performance and cost of the major alternatives for H storage, pressurized cylinder, metal hydride, liquefaction, and storage on activated C, is presented. The MACS system is demonstrated to be an attractive method for advanced H energy storage.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaL1cXnvVSltA%253D%253D&md5=62d7955436e8d323be96dcbbf5cf8485
        (d) Chahine, R.; Bose, T. K. Int. J. Hydrogen Energy 1994, 19, 161
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        5d
        Low-pressure adsorption storage of hydrogen
        Chahine, R.; Bose, T. K.
        International Journal of Hydrogen Energy (1994), 19 (2), 161-4CODEN: IJHEDX; ISSN:0360-3199.
        The amt. of gas that can be stored in an adsorption system is dictated by the nature of the adsorbent material and the operating conditions of the storage system, namely the storage pressure and temp. This paper describes the impact of these factors on H2 storage in zeolites and and AX-21 activated C. The discussion is based on measurements of hydrogen adsorption on com. available and densified adsorbents. The measurements were carried out at 1-80 atm and at different storage temps. using a high-pressure volumetric method. The results show that the adsorption technique could provide a viable method for hydrogen storage.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK2cXotFGgtA%253D%253D&md5=6bd33c56920a4bddf5e957ce1afa17b1
        (e) Zhou, Y.; Zhou, L. Sci. China, Ser. B 1996, 39, 598
        [CAS], Google Scholar
        5e
        Experimental study on high-pressure adsorption of hydrogen on activated carbon
        Zhou, Yaping; Zhou, Li
        Science in China, Series B: Chemistry (1996), 39 (6), 598-607CODEN: SCBCFQ; ISSN:1006-9291. (Science in China Press)
        A systematic measurement of H2 adsorption on activated carbon over a wide scope of conditions was completed for the 1st time by using a novel cryostat developed by the authors. The equil. temps. covered 77-298 K with intervals of ∼ 20 K, and the equil. pressures increased from 0 to ∼ 7 MPa. A set of adsorption/desorption isotherms was obtained by a std. volumetric method. This set of exptl. data was fitted to all the well-known models of type-I isotherms, and the Dubinin-Astakhov (D-A) equation gave the best fit. On the basis of D-A model, one can predict adsorption with relative error ± 4%. A 3-dimensional adsorption surface was also constructed, and the isosteric heat of adsorption was detd. anal. Except in the low pressure area, the calcd. values agree well with the exptl. ones. Finally, the problems encountered in applying the D-A equation to supercrit. adsorption is discussed.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK2sXjtVCkuw%253D%253D&md5=540a80c508e80000f7f7cf3195dc4ce0
        (f) Wang, Q.; Johnson, J. K. J. Chem. Phys. 1999, 110, 577
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        5f
        Molecular simulation of hydrogen adsorption in single-walled carbon nanotubes and idealized carbon slit pores
        Wang, Qinyu; Johnson, J. Karl
        Journal of Chemical Physics (1999), 110 (1), 577-586CODEN: JCPSA6; ISSN:0021-9606. (American Institute of Physics)
        The adsorption of hydrogen gas into single-walled carbon nanotubes (SWNTs) and idealized carbon slit pores is studied by computer simulation. Hydrogen-hydrogen interactions are modeled with the Silvera-Goldman potential. The Crowell-Brown potential is used to model the hydrogen-carbon interactions. Calcns. include adsorption inside the tubes, in the interstitial regions of tube arrays, and on the outside surface of isolated tubes. Quantum effects are included through implementation of the path integral formalism. Comparison with classical simulations gives an indication of the importance of quantum effects for hydrogen adsorption. Quantum effects are important even at 298 K for adsorption in tube interstices. Presented simulations were compare with exptl. data for SWNTs, graphitic nanofibers, and activated carbon. Adsorption isotherms from simulations are in reasonable agreement with exptl. data for activated carbon, but do not confirm the large uptake reported for SWNTs and nanofibers. Although the adsorption potential for hydrogen in SWNTs is enhanced relative to slit pores of the same size, presented calcns. show that the storage capacity of an array of tubes is less than that for idealized slit pore geometries, except at very low pressures. Ambient temp. isotherms indicate that an array of nanotubes is not a suitable sorbent material for achieving DOE targets for vehicular hydrogen storage.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK1MXivFKrtA%253D%253D&md5=f3c3d17610f9416de3ea701efbad0a35
        (g) de la Casa-Lillo, M. A.; Lamari-Darkrim, F.; Cazorla-Amoros, D.; Linares-Solano, A. J. Phys. Chem. B 2002, 106, 10930
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        5g
        Hydrogen Storage in Activated Carbons and Activated Carbon Fibers
        de la Casa-Lillo, M. A.; Lamari-Darkrim, F.; Cazorla-Amoros, D.; Linares-Solano, A.
        Journal of Physical Chemistry B (2002), 106 (42), 10930-10934CODEN: JPCBFK; ISSN:1520-6106. (American Chemical Society)
        Hydrogen storage has been studied in a large variety of activated carbons and activated carbon fibers and a wide range of pressures (up to 70 MPa). The exptl. technique used has good reliability, and the expts. performed have a small error and high reproducibility. This seems to be essential to get trustworthy conclusions. In these samples, we have not found large amts. of hydrogen adsorbed. In any case, an activated carbon obtained by a simple prepn. method provides hydrogen storage values at 10 MPa close to 1 wt.% (i.e., a value close to the target from an application point of view). The exptl. results have been compared with theor. data found in the literature, and an important agreement can be obsd. From this study, we conclude that the optimum pore size for hydrogen storage is that which can hold two layers of adsorbed hydrogen. This work also considers practical aspects related to hydrogen storage in activated carbons and activated carbon fibers.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD38Xnt12lu7o%253D&md5=06ffa6f9264b0baee0effa0d54d457c6
        (h) Wang, H.; Gao, Q.; Hu, J. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2009, 131, 7016
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        5h
        High Hydrogen Storage Capacity of Porous Carbons Prepared by Using Activated Carbon
        Wang, Huanlei; Gao, Qiuming; Hu, Juan
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2009), 131 (20), 7016-7022CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        A kind of activated carbon with further carbon dioxide and potassium hydroxide activations for hydrogen storage was studied. The carbon dioxide and potassium hydroxide activations have apparently different effects on the pore structures and textures of the activated carbon which closely assocd. with the hydrogen storage properties. The potassium hydroxide activation can remarkably donate microporosity to the frameworks of the activated carbon. One of the resultant porous carbons exhibited a high surface area of up to 3190 m2 g-1 and large gravimetric hydrogen uptake capacity of 7.08% at 77 K and 20 bar, which is one of the largest data reported for the porous carbon materials. Probably the porous carbon with large amts. of active sites, high surface area, and high micropore vol. related to optimum pore size could achieve high gravimetric hydrogen storage.
        >> More from SciFinder ®

        (a) Das, L. M. Int. J. Hydrogen Energy 1996, 21, 789
