        (n) Yazaydin, A. O.; Snurr, R. Q.; Park, T.-H.; Koh, K.; Liu, J.; LeVan, M. D.; Benin, A. I.; Jakubczak, P.; Lanuza, M.; Galloway, D. B.; Low, J. J.; Willis, R. R. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2009, 131, 18198
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        12n
        Screening of Metal-Organic Frameworks for Carbon Dioxide Capture from Flue Gas Using a Combined Experimental and Modeling Approach
        Yazaydin, A. Ozgur; Snurr, Randall Q.; Park, Tae-Hong; Koh, Kyoungmoo; Liu, Jian; LeVan, M. Douglas; Benin, Annabelle I.; Jakubczak, Paulina; Lanuza, Mary; Galloway, Douglas B.; Low, John J.; Willis, Richard R.
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2009), 131 (51), 18198-18199CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        A diverse collection of 14 metal-org. frameworks (MOF) for flue gas CO2 capture are reported. Synthesis, characterization, and adsorption measurements for about half the MOF are reported; adsorption data were collected from the literature for the remaining MOF. The diversity of the selected materials will help improve the understanding fo MOF CO2 capture. Also, these data were used to validate a general strategy for mol. modeling of CO2 and other small mols. in MOF. This strategy is fully predicting with no parameter-fitting. This approach can be used to rapidly screen addnl. MOF, saving large amts. of exptl. time and costs. Grand canonical Monte Carlo simulations were performed for a model which included electrostatic and Lennard-Jones interactions among atoms in the system. The framework and individual CO2 mols. are considered to be rigid. Interactions among CO2 mols. were modeled with the TraAPPE force field (J.J. Potoff and J.I. Siepmann, 2001); Lennard-Jones parameters for MOF atoms were taken from DREIDING (S.L. Mayo, et al., 1990) and UFF (A.K. Rappe, et al., 1992) force fields. Partial charges on MOF atoms were derived from d. functional theory calcns.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXhsFShsr7L&md5=ee067ec4cee9d1095897b19d957671db
        (o) An, J.; Fiorella, R. P.; Geib, S. J.; Rosi, N. L. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2009, 131, 8401
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        12o
        Synthesis, Structure, Assembly, and Modulation of the CO2 Adsorption Properties of a Zinc-Adeninate Macrocycle
        An, Jihyun; Fiorella, Richard P.; Geib, Steven J.; Rosi, Nathaniel L.
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2009), 131 (24), 8401-8403CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        The prepn. and self-assembly and crystal structure of the zinc adeninate macrocyclic complex [Zn6(adeninate)6(pyridine)6(dimethylcarbamate)6] is described. The macrocycles self-assemble through adenine-adenine hydrogen bonding interactions into a 3-dimensional porous cryst. material that maintains its structural integrity after removal of guest mols. and coordinated pyridine mols. By adjusting the activation temp. prior to gas adsorption measurements, the size of the pore aperture can be modulated to afford unique gas sorption properties including selective gas adsorption and CO2 sequestration.

        (a) Yildirim, T.; Hartman, M. R. Phys. Rev. Lett. 2005, 95, 215504
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        13a
        Direct observation of hydrogen adsorption sites and nanocage formation in metal-organic frameworks
        Yildirim T; Hartman M R
        Physical review letters (2005), 95 (21), 215504 ISSN:0031-9007.
        The hydrogen adsorption sites in MOF5 were determined using neutron powder diffraction along with first-principles calculations. The metal-oxide cluster is primarily responsible for the adsorption while the organic linker plays only a secondary role. Equally important, at low temperatures and high-concentration, molecules form unique interlinked high-symmetry nanoclusters with intermolecular distances as small as 3.0 Angstrom and H(2) uptake as high as 11 wt %. These results hold the key to optimizing metal-organic framework (MOF) materials for hydrogen storage applications and also suggest that MOFs can be used as templates to create artificial interlinked hydrogen nanocages with novel properties.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADC%252BD2Mnps1OksQ%253D%253D&md5=4a0b159904955303cb88a18346bcc51c
        (b) Hartman, M. R.; Peterson, V. K.; Liu, Y.; Kaye, S. S.; Long, J. R. Chem. Mater. 2006, 18, 3221
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        13b
        Neutron Diffraction and Neutron Vibrational Spectroscopy Studies of Hydrogen Adsorption in the Prussian Blue Analogue Cu3[Co(CN)6]2
        Hartman, Michael R.; Peterson, Vanessa K.; Liu, Yun; Kaye, Steven S.; Long, Jeffrey R.
        Chemistry of Materials (2006), 18 (14), 3221-3224CODEN: CMATEX; ISSN:0897-4756. (American Chemical Society)
        The adsorption of mol. hydrogen in the Prussian blue analog Cu3[Co(CN)6]2 was studied using high-resoln. neutron powder diffraction and neutron vibrational spectroscopy. Rietveld structural refinement of the neutron data for hydrogen loadings of 1, 2, and ∼2.3 H2/Cu showed that the hydrogen was absorbed at 2 sites within the structure. The most prominent adsorption site, located at the (1/4, 1/4, 1/4) crystallog. site, was an interstitial location within the structure. The 2nd adsorption site was assocd. with exposed Cu2+ ion coordination sites that result from the presence of [Co(CN)6]3- vacancies within the structure of the material. The rotational-vibrational d. of states of the adsorbed hydrogen was probed using neutron vibrational spectroscopy and showed a range of local binding potentials for the adsorbed hydrogen.
        >> More from SciFinder ®

        13d
        Hydrogen Storage in a Prototypical Zeolitic Imidazolate Framework-8
        Wu, Hui; Zhou, Wei; Yildirim, Taner
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2007), 129 (17), 5314-5315CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        Using the difference Fourier anal. of n powder diffraction data with 1st-principles calcns., detailed structural information such as Me group orientation, H adsorption sites, and binding energies within the nanopore structure of ZIF8 (Zn(MeIM)2 with MeIM = 2-methylimidazole) (ZIF is an abbreviation for zeolitic imidazolate frameworks) was obtained. The 2 strongest adsorption sites identified are both directly assocd. with the org. linkers instead of the ZnN4 clusters, in contrast to classical MOFs where the metal-oxide clusters are the primary adsorption sites. These observations can be used to optimize this new class of ZIF materials for H storage. At high H2-loadings the ZIF8 structure is capable of holding up to 28 H2 mols. (i.e., 4.2%) as highly sym. novel 3-dimensional interlinked H2-nanoclusters with relatively short H2-H2 distances compared to solid H2. Hence, ZIF compds. with robust chem. stability can be also an ideal template host-material to generate mol. nanostructures with novel properties.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2sXktVyhtb8%253D&md5=2b6bd3bbda6a8aaa302918dc940c270a
        (e) Rowsell, J. L. C.; Eckert, J.; Yaghi, O. M. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2005, 127, 14904
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        13e
        Characterization of H2 Binding Sites in Prototypical Metal-Organic Frameworks by Inelastic Neutron Scattering
        Rowsell, Jesse L. C.; Eckert, Juergen; Yaghi, Omar M.
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2005), 127 (42), 14904-14910CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        The hindered rotor transitions of H2 adsorbed in the chem. related and prototypical porous metal-org. frameworks IRMOF-1, IRMOF-8, IRMOF-11, and MOF-177 were studied by inelastic neutron scattering to gain information on the specifics of H2 binding in this class of adsorbents. Remarkably sharp and complex spectra of these materials signify a diversity of well-defined binding sites. Similarities in the spectral features as a function of H2 loading and correlations with recent crystallog. studies were used to assign transitions ranging in rotational barrier from <0.04 to 0.6 kcal/mol as corresponding to localized adsorption sites on the org. and inorg. components of these frameworks. Binding of H2 at the inorg. cluster sites is affected by the nature of the org. link and is strongest in IRMOF-11 in accord with adsorption isotherm data. The sites on the org. link have lower binding energies, but a much greater capacity for increases in H2 loading, which demonstrates their importance for hydrogen uptake by these materials.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2MXhtVGis7%252FF&md5=cce77a13ade28d02f02cb8be3a28afcb
        (f) Hubner, O.; Gloss, A.; Fichtner, M.; Klopper, W. J. Phys. Chem. A 2004, 108, 3019
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        13f
        On the Interaction of Dihydrogen with Aromatic Systems
        Huebner, Olaf; Gloess, Andreas; Fichtner, Maximilian; Klopper, Wim
        Journal of Physical Chemistry A (2004), 108 (15), 3019-3023CODEN: JPCAFH; ISSN:1089-5639. (American Chemical Society)
        Second-order Moller-Plesset (MP2) calcns. (using the approx. resoln. of the identity, RI-MP2) in the TZVPP basis are performed to study the interaction of mol. hydrogen with the arom. systems C6H5X (X = H, F, OH, NH2, CH3, and CN), C10H8 (naphthalene and azulene), C14H10 (anthracene), C24H12 (coronene), p-C6H4(COOH)2 (terephthalic acid), and p-C6H4(COOLi)2 (dilithium terephthalate). Various adsorption positions are studied for C6H5F. The most favorable configuration places H2 above the arom. plane with its axis pointing toward the middle of the ring. The electronic (van der Waals) interaction energy for the differently substituted benzenes correlates with the ability of the substituents to enrich the arom. system electronically. The largest interaction energy (among the singly substituted benzenes) is found for aniline (4.5 kJ mol-1). Enlarging the arom. system increases the interaction energy; the value for coronene amts. to 5.4 kJ mol-1. Extending the basis set and including terms linear in the interelectronic distances increases the interaction energy by about 1 kJ mol-1 relative to that of the TZVPP basis, whereas the inclusion of higher excitations by coupled-cluster calcns. (including all single and double excitations with a perturbative est. of triples, CCSD(T)) decreases the interaction energy by about the same amt.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2cXitFektb8%253D&md5=2768ae081fccf68fef02bcf01cbb6be7
        (g) Liu, Y.; Brown, C. M.; Neumann, D. A.; Peterson, V. K.; Kepert, C. J. J. Alloys Compd. 2007, 446–447, 385
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        13g
        Inelastic neutron scattering of H2 adsorbed in HKUST-1
        Liu, Y.; Brown, C. M.; Neumann, D. A.; Peterson, V. K.; Kepert, C. J.
        Journal of Alloys and Compounds (2007), 446-447 (), 385-388CODEN: JALCEU; ISSN:0925-8388. (Elsevier B.V.)
        A series of inelastic neutron scattering (INS) investigations of H adsorbed in activated HKUST-1 (Cu3(1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate)2) result in INS spectra with rich features, even at very low loading (<1.0 H2:Cu). The distinct inelastic features in the spectra show that there are 3 binding sites that are progressively populated when the H2 loading is less than 2.0 H2:Cu, which is consistent with the result obtained from previous neutron powder diffraction expts. The temp. dependence of the INS spectra reveals the relative binding enthalpies for H2 at each site.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2sXhtFKltrjF&md5=d126eca1d43889d56c02e693baa2b58c

        (a) Yang, C.; Wang, X.; Omary, M. A. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2007, 129, 15454

        14a
        Fluorous Metal-Organic Frameworks for High-Density Gas Adsorption
        Yang, Chi; Wang, Xiaoping; Omary, Mohammad A.
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2007), 129 (50), 15454-15455CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        A fluorous metal-org. framework, FMOF-1, was obtained by reaction of Ag(I) with 3,5-bis(trifluoromethyl)-1,2,4-triazolate (Tz), giving rise to a neutral, H-free, extended 3-dimensional nanotubular porous framework consisting of tetranuclear clusters [Ag4Tz6]2- connected by three-coordinate Ag(I) centers. The fluoro-lined channels and cavities of the framework show hysteretic adsorption of H2 with a volumetric capacity of 41 kg/m3 at 77 K and 64 bar. Ag2[Ag4Tz6] also exhibits very high adsorptions for O2 and N2 with volumetric uptake of ∼550 and 400 kg/m3 at 77 K even at very low pressures (<10-2 bar).
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2sXhtlKru7nO&md5=ffa73c5fbb7e78024ae2fa4e88b21b97
        (b) Yang, C.; Wang, X. P.; Omary, M. A. Angew. Chem., Int. Ed. 2009, 48, 2500
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        14b
        Crystallographic observation of dynamic gas adsorption sites and thermal expansion in a breathable fluorous metal-organic framework
        Yang, Chi; Wang, Xiaoping; Omary, Mohammad A.
        Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2009), 48 (14), 2500-2505CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        Cooling a single crystal of a microporous fluorous metal-org. framework under ambient atm. leads to very large breathing upon gas adsorption, during which multiple N2 mols. are filled into channels and cages. While the framework exhibits remarkable pos. thermal expansion under vacuum, a gigantic apparent neg. thermal expansion takes place when the crystal is exposed to N2 at ambient pressure.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXktlOms74%253D&md5=46cb3e5ea1f0b64fd5ae83b44c847170
        (c) Fischer, R. A.; Woll, C. Angew. Chem., Int. Ed. 2008, 47, 8164
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        14c
        Functionalized coordination space in metal-organic frameworks
        Fischer, Roland A.; Woell, Christof
        Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2008), 47 (43), 8164-8168CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        A review. Discussion focuses on two significant advances in the development of metal-org. frameworks (MOFs): (1) perfluoro MOFs with an outstanding volumetric gas uptake and hysteretic sorption of dihydrogen; (2) the modular synthesis of functional MOFs involving a two-component framework, in which one component is an integral component of the framework and the other can be exchanged after formation of the matrix.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1cXht12nsb%252FO&md5=1ec50f5c6d405e4130f69b4309aa6cfa

        14d
        Enhanced H2 adsorption enthalpy in the low-surface area, partially fluorinated coordination polymer Zn5(triazole)6(tetrafluoroterephthalate)2(H2O)2·4H2O
        Hulvey, Zeric; Falcao, Eduardo H. L.; Eckert, Juergen; Cheetham, Anthony K.
        Journal of Materials Chemistry (2009), 19 (25), 4307-4309CODEN: JMACEP; ISSN:0959-9428. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        A porous coordination polymer contg. zinc, 1,2,4-triazolate, and tetrafluoroterephthalate, Zn5(triazole)6(tetrafluoroterephthalate)2(H2O)2·4H2O, was prepd. and characterized by x-ray crystallog. It displays a high physisorptive hydrogen adsorption enthalpy of 8 kJ/mol, as a result of fluorine atoms exposed to the pore surface and the structure's small pore size.

        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXnt1amsr0%253D&md5=3427aba1cabde38da0b4f4c3f637770c
        (e) Hulvey, Z.; Sava, D. A.; Eckert, J.; Cheetham, A. K. Inorg. Chem. 2011, 50, 403

        14e
        Hydrogen Storage in a Highly Interpenetrated and Partially Fluorinated Metal-Organic Framework
        Hulvey, Zeric; Sava, Dorina A.; Eckert, Juergen; Cheetham, Anthony K.
        Inorganic Chemistry (Washington, DC, United States) (2011), 50 (2), 403-405CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
        A partially fluorinated metal-org. framework, Zn(bpe)(tftpa)·cyclohexanone [bpe = 1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethane; tftpa = tetrafluoro terephthalate], was synthesized and its H2 storage properties are reported. The structure is highly interpenetrated yet contains templating cyclohexanone mols., which can be removed to give a porous material with F atoms exposed to the pore surface. The material adsorbs 1.04% H2 at 77 K and 1 atm with an adsorption enthalpy (Qst) of 6.2 kJ/mol, which represents a slight enhancement in the binding strength due to the presence of F atoms over comparable metal-org. frameworks, which bind through purely physisorptive methods.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXhsFOqtrbN&md5=b4f8b5fa38724e791f3dba6fb5409fc7
        (f) Pan, L.; Sander, M. B.; Huang, X.; Li, J.; Smith, M.; Bittner, E.; Bockrath, B.; Johnson, J. K. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2004, 126, 1308
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        14f
        Microporous Metal Organic Materials: Promising Candidates as Sorbents for Hydrogen Storage
        Pan, Long; Sander, Michelle B.; Huang, Xiaoying; Li, Jing; Smith, Milton; Bittner, Edward; Bockrath, Bradley; Johnson, J. Karl
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2004), 126 (5), 1308-1309CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        Although extensive efforts have been made to improve H storage techniques, there is no viable storage technol. capable of meeting the DOE cost and performance targets. New materials with significantly improved H adsorption capability are needed. Microporous metal coordination materials (MMOMs) are promising sorbents for H adsorption. These materials possess phys. characteristics similar to those of single-walled C nanotubes and they also have a no. of advantages. A novel MMOM structure and its room-temp. H adsorption properties are presented.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2cXksFClsA%253D%253D&md5=f1b68f3ac25dc59c3ecc58c5300d5c9f
        (g) Yang, W.; Lin, X.; Blake, A. J.; Wilson, C.; Hubberstey, P.; Champness, N. R.; Schroder, M. Inorg. Chem. 2009, 48, 11067
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        14g
        Self-Assembly of Metal-Organic Coordination Polymers Constructed from a Bent Dicarboxylate Ligand: Diversity of Coordination Modes, Structures, and Gas Adsorption
        Yang, Wenbin; Lin, Xiang; Blake, Alexander J.; Wilson, Claire; Hubberstey, Peter; Champness, Neil R.; Schroder, Martin
        Inorganic Chemistry (2009), 48 (23), 11067-11078CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
        The authors synthesized five new metal-org. coordination polymers incorporating the bent ligand H2hfipbb [4,4'-(hexafluoroisopropylidene)bis(benzoic acid)] with different transition metal ions and co-ligands via solvothermal reactions to give [Zn2(hfipbb)2(py)2]·DMF (1), [Zn2(hfipbb)2(4,4'-bipy)(H2O)] (2), [Zn2(hfipbb)2(bpdab)]·2DMF (3), [Cd2(hfipbb)2(DMF)2]·2DMF (4), and [Co(hfipbb)(dpp)]·MeOH (5) (py = pyridine, 4,4'-bipy = 4,4'-bipyridine, bpdab = 1,4-bis(4-pyridyl)-2,3-diaza-1,3-butadiene, dpp = 1,3-di(4-pyridyl)propane). Compd. 1 displays a 2-fold 2D→2D parallel interpenetrated layer network with 1-dimensional (1D) helical channels, while 3 exhibits a three-dimensional pillared helical-layer open framework of α-Po topol. based upon binuclear paddle-wheel units. In compds. 2 and 5, binuclear motifs with double carboxylate bridges are linked by hfipbb2- ligands into a 1-dimensional ribbon, which are further assembled into two-dimensional non-interpenetrated (4,4) layers via bipyridyl co-ligands. However, the different bridging modes of hfipbb2- ligands and the different disposition of the coordinated co-ligands around metal ions result in subtle differences in the final architecture. Thus, 2 is based on a binuclear cluster node, double-stranded hfipbb2- linkers, and single-stranded 4,4'-bipy linkers, while 5 is based on a binuclear cluster node and hfipbb2- and dpp linkers which are both double-stranded. Among these compds., the Cd(II) complex 4 is possibly the most interesting because it represents a rare example in which metal centers are linked by carboxylate groups into infinite chains further joined together by hfipbb2- spacers to form a 2-dimensional network with tubular helical channels. All these coordination polymers exhibit low solvent-accessible vols. Both 3 and 4 retain structural integrity and permanent microporosity upon evacuation of guest mols., with H uptakes of 0.57 and 0.78%, resp., at 20 bar and 77 K.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXhtlCkurfN&md5=dca16e4f836c1063826159080f6f764b
        (h) Fernandez, C. A.; Thallapally, P. K.; Motkuri, R. K.; Nune, S. K.; Sumrak, J. C.; Tian, J.; Liu, J. Cryst. Growth Des. 2010, 10, 1037
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        14h
        Gas-Induced Expansion and Contraction of a Fluorinated Metal-Organic Framework
        Fernandez, Carlos A.; Thallapally, Praveen K.; Motkuri, Radha Kishan; Nune, Satish K.; Sumrak, Joseph C.; Tian, Jian; Liu, Jun
        Crystal Growth & Design (2010), 10 (3), 1037-1039CODEN: CGDEFU; ISSN:1528-7483. (American Chemical Society)
        Synthesis and gas sorption properties of a novel fluorinated metal-org. framework of zinc(II) using com. available 2,2'-bis(4-carboxyphenyl)hexafluoropropane is reported with high selectivity toward CO2, H2S, and SO2 as well as breathing motion upon solvent removal and gas inclusion.

      15. 15
        Chun, H.; Dybtsev, D. N.; Kim, H.; Kim., K. Chem.—Eur. J. 2005, 11, 3521
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        15
        Synthesis, X-ray crystal structures, and gas sorption properties of pillared square grid nets based on paddle-wheel motifs: Implications for hydrogen storage in porous materials
        Chun, Hyungphil; Dybtsev, Danil N.; Kim, Hyunuk; Kim, Kimoon
        Chemistry - A European Journal (2005), 11 (12), 3521-3529CODEN: CEUJED; ISSN:0947-6539. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        A systematic modulation of org. ligands connecting dinuclear paddle-wheel motifs leads to isomorphous metal-org. porous materials that have a three-dimensional connectivity and interconnected pores. Arom. dicarboxylates such as 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate (1,4-bdc), tetramethylterephthalate (tmbdc), 1,4-naphthalenedicarboxylate (1,4-ndc), tetrafluoroterephthalate (tfbdc), or 2,6-naphthalenedicarboxylate (2,6-ndc) are linear linkers that form two-dimensional layers, and diamine ligands, 4-diazabicyclo[2.2.2]octane (dabco) or 4,4'-dipyridyl (bpy), coordinate at both sides of Zn2 paddle-wheel units to bridge the layers vertically. The resulting open frameworks [Zn2(1,4-bdc)2(dabco)] (1), [Zn2(1,4-bdc)(tmbdc)(dabco)] (2), [Zn2(tmbdc)2(dabco)] (3), [Zn2(1,4-ndc)2(dabco)] (4), [Zn2(tfbdc)2(dabco)] (5), and [Zn2(tmbdc)2(bpy)] (8) possess varying size of pores and free apertures originating from the side groups of the 1,4-bdc derivs. [Zn2(1,4-bdc)2(bpy)] (6) and [Zn2(2,6-ndc)2(bpy)] (7) have two- and 3-fold interpenetrating structures, resp. The noninterpenetrating frameworks (1-5 and 8) possess surface areas at 1450-2090 m2g-1 and H sorption capacities of 1.7-2.1% at 78 K and 1 atm. A detailed anal. of the sorption data in conjunction with structural similarities and differences concludes that porous materials with straight channels and large openings do not perform better than those with wavy channels and small openings in terms of H storage through physisorption.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2MXlt1ygt70%253D&md5=6b32569fb5a054ae4872481379e3463c
      16. 16

        Cu-TBA-1: C86H50N40O22Cu9, Mr = 2567.52, Orthorhombic, Pnn2, a = 13.464(8) Å; b = 29.985(17) Å; c = 19.717(11); V = 7960(8) Å3, Dc = 1.071 g cm–3, μ = 1.235 mm–1, 13908 total reflection, 7177 unique (Rint = 0.1456), T = 293(2), final R indices (I > 2σ(I)): R1 = 0.0778, wR2 = 0.1731, Goodness-of-fit = 0.910. Cu-TBA-2: C21H23N9O6Cu2, Mr = 624.58, Orthorhombic, Imm2, a = 7.119(6) Å; b = 21.58(2) Å; c = 9.100(8); V = 1398(2) Å3, Dc = 1.477 g cm–3, μ = 1.572 mm–1, 1611 total reflection, 1459 unique (Rint = 0.0701), T = 293(2), final R indices (I > 2σ(I)): R1 = 0.0604, wR2 = 0.1503, Goodness-of-fit = 1.077.       17. 17

        Here it should be noted that Fluorinated Metal Organic Framework (F-MOF) referred here is not fully fluorinated, but it is the partially fluorinated where only one hydrogen atom from 2 position of 4-TBA is replaced by fluorine.

        (a) Song, W.-C.; Li, J.-R.; Song, P.-C.; Tao, Y.; Yu, Q.; Tong, X.-L.; Bu, X.-H. Inorg. Chem. 2009, 48, 3792
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        17a
        Tuning the Framework Topologies of CoII-Doped ZnII-Tetrazole-benzoate Coordination Polymers by Ligand Modifications: Structures and Spectral Studies
        Song, Wei-Chao; Li, Jian-Rong; Song, Peng-Chao; Tao, Ying; Yu, Qun; Tong, Xiao-Lan; Bu, Xian-He
        Inorganic Chemistry (2009), 48 (8), 3792-3799CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
        In the authors' continuing efforts to explore the effects of ligand modifications on the structures and properties of their metal complexes, the authors studied the in situ [2 + 3] cycloaddn. reactions of benzonitrile, o-phthalodinitrile, 3-cyanobenzoic acid, 4-cyanobenzoic acid with NaN3 in the presence of ZnII and/or CoII salts under hydrothermal conditions, and obtained four new CoII-doped ZnII-tetrazole-benzoate coordination polymers of [CoxZn1-x(Lm)y]n [5-phenyl-1H-tetrazole (HL1) for 1, 2-(1H-tetrazol-5-yl)benzoic acid (H2L2) for 2, 3-(1H-tetrazol-5-yl)benzoic acid (H2L3) for 3, and 4-(1H-tetrazol-5-yl)benzoic acid (H2L4) for 4]. The structure of 1 shows a classical diamondoid net, while 2 and 3, take 2-dimensional layer structure with (4.62)(4.6.4.6) topol. and 3-dimensional SrAl2 topol., resp. The structure of 4 exhibits a four-connected 3-dimensional network with rare nondiamondoid 66 topol. The coordination modes of the center metal and the ligands in the four complexes are almost the same, being tetrahedral or four-connected, but their topologies are quite different. Thus, the four structurally related ligands allow anal. of the effects of the disposition of a 2nd functional carboxylate group on an arom. ring and the twist angles of the carboxylate and tetrazolyl out of the plane of the arom. ring on the overall structural topol. of their complexes. The CoII ions were doped into the ZnII complexes, as confirmed by their macroscopical colors, inductively coupled plasma (ICP) anal. and UV-visible spectra. The photoluminescence of the four complexes in the solid state at room temp. was briefly studied.
        >> More from SciFinder ®

        17b
        A Three-Dimensional Porous and Magnetic Framework Constructed from {Cu4(μ4-Cl)}+7 Clusters and 4-(1H-Tetrazol-5yl)-benzoic Acid, (Me2NH2)[Cu4Cl(tba)4(H2O)4]·2DMF
        Ouellette, Wayne; Liu, Hongxue; Whitenack, Kelly; O'Connor, Charles J.; Zubieta, Jon
        Crystal Growth & Design (2009), 9 (10), 4258-4261CODEN: CGDEFU; ISSN:1528-7483. (American Chemical Society)
        The hydrothermal reaction of CuCl2·2H2O and 4-(1H tetrazol-5-yl)-HOBz (H2tba) in the presence of excess HCl yielded the three-dimensional material (Me2NH2)[Cu4Cl(tba)4(H2O)4]·2DMF. The structure is constructed from {Cu4(μ4-Cl)(H2O)4}7+ clusters linked through tba2- ligands into an open framework with 57% void vol. The microporosity and magnetic properties of the material were studied.

        Blue-green photoluminescent 5- and 10-connected metal 5-(4'-carboxy-phenyl)tetrazolate coordination polymers
        Jiang, Tao; Zhao, Yan-Fei; Zhang, Xian-Ming
        Inorganic Chemistry Communications (2007), 10 (10), 1194-1197CODEN: ICCOFP; ISSN:1387-7003. (Elsevier B.V.)
        Hydrothermal reaction of Zn/Cd salts, NaN3 and 4-cyanobenzoic acid via in situ [2 + 3] cycloaddn. generated two blue-green photoluminescent coordination polymers [Zn(cptta)(H2O)] (1) and [Cd(cptta)(H2O)] (2) (H2cptta = 5-(4'-carboxy-phenyl)tetrazole). When only metal ions are considered as nodes, 1 shows rare 5-connected Shubnikov plane topol. type and 2 has unprecedented 10-connected {312.424.59} topol. type.

        17d
        A Novel Metal-Organic Network with High Thermal Stability: Nonlinear Optical and Photoluminescent Properties

        Inorganic Chemistry (2008), 47 (18), 7945-7947CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
        A novel zinc(II) 4-(tetrazol-5-yl)benzoate coordination polymer with an in situ generated tetrazole ligand exhibits the gsi (γ-silicon) topol. and high thermal stability. This compd. possesses second-order nonlinear optical and interesting heat-induced photoluminescent properties.

        Interweaving of single-helical and equal double-helical chains with the same helical axis in a 3D metal-organic framework

        18
        Synthesis and quantitative structure-activity relationship analysis of N-triiodoallyl- and N-iodopropargylazoles. New antifungal agents
        Koyama, Masao; Ohtani, Noriko; Kai, Fumio; Moriguchi, Ikuo; Inouye, Shigeharu
        Journal of Medicinal Chemistry (1987), 30 (3), 552-62CODEN: JMCMAR; ISSN:0022-2623.
        A new series of N-(2,3,3-triiodoallyl)- and N-(3-iodopropargyl)azole derivs. (100 compds.) with pyrrole, pyrazole, imidazole, triazole, and tetrazole nuclei were synthesized with the aid of quant. structure-activity relationship (QSAR) anal. to obtain potent antifungal agents. Starting from the derivs. of nitropyrrole-contg. antibiotics, the QSAR anal. of the pyrrole derivs. against Candida albicans and Trichophyton mentagrophytes strains indicated the pos. contribution of the nitro group and the neg. effect of the size of the mol. Further application of the QSAR anal. on the multiazole derivs. revealed the importance of hydrophobicity and electronegativity as well as steric effects on their activities and led to the synthesis of one of the most potent iodo compds., (triiodoallyl)tetrazole (I).

      26. 26
        Cracknell, R. F. Phys. Chem. Chem. Phys. 2001, 3, 2091
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        26
        Molecular simulation of hydrogen adsorption in graphitic nanofibers
        Cracknell, Roger F.
        Physical Chemistry Chemical Physics (2001), 3 (11), 2091-2097CODEN: PPCPFQ; ISSN:1463-9076. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        The uptake of hydrogen in graphitic nanofibers of 40% by wt. were published. If these results are confirmed, then this class of material could be a suitable storage medium for hydrogen for use in fuel cell vehicles. Results are reported for grand canonical Monte Carlo simulation of hydrogen adsorption in graphitic pores. A classical technique was employed but the results obtained were shown to be consistent with previous path integral Monte Carlo calcns. of Wang and Johnson (Q. Wang and J. K. Johnson, J. Chem. Phys., 1999, 110, 577; Q. Wang and J. K. Johnson, J. Phys. Chem. B, 1999, 103, 277). The interaction between hydrogen and the graphitic surface was modeled initially by dispersion forces. The predicted uptake (up to 1.5%) was much lower than the Baker-Rodriguez results. The results were found to be fairly insensitive as to whether the hydrogen mol. was modeled as a Lennard-Jones sphere or a dumbbell fluid with two Lennard-Jones sites. Two models for a hypothetical potential for chemisorption were also used in the simulation. The potential was based on calcn. of the interaction between at. hydrogen and a graphitic surface. Adsorption of up to 17 wt.% was measured with the stronger model potential but there was negligible desorption at ambient pressure, making it impractical. A more plausible, though still hypothetical, potential gave loadings of up to 8 wt.% in the model system. These results are still much lower than the Baker-Rodriguez data in spite of the fact that there is no evidence to suggest that chemisorption actually occurs in a real system.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3MXjs1yktrY%253D&md5=6bacfc33e17ce59db645d8654923e170
      27. 27
        Rappe, A. K.; Casewit, C. J.; Colwell, K. S.; Goddard, W. A.; Skiff, W. M. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 1992, 114, 10024
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        27
        UFF, a full periodic table force field for molecular mechanics and molecular dynamics simulations
        Rappe, A. K.; Casewit, C. J.; Colwell, K. S.; Goddard, W. A., III; Skiff, W. M.
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (1992), 114 (25), 10024-35CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863.
        A new mol. mechanics force field, the Universal force field (UFF), is described wherein the force field parameters are estd. using general rules based only on the element, its hybridization and its connectivity. The force field functional forms, parameters, and generating formulas for the full periodic table are presented.

        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK38Xmtl2qur8%253D&md5=cf41e8bb9ad299fd5d79f070d690afe1
      28. 28

        The experimental pattern of Cu-TBA-1 has a few diffraction lines that are unindexed and some that are slightly broadened in comparison with those simulated patterns. This is probably due to the loss of either DMF or EtOH molecules from the lattice or phase change due to grinding while at analysis.

      29. 29
        (a) Zhao, X.; Xiao, B.; Fletcher, A. J.; Thomas, K. M.; Bradshaw, D.; Rosseinsky, M. J. Science 2004, 306, 1012
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        29a
        Hysteretic Adsorption and Desorption of Hydrogen by Nanoporous Metal-Organic Frameworks
        Zhao, Xuebo; Xiao, Bo; Fletcher, Ashleigh J.; Thomas, K. Mark; Bradshaw, Darren; Rosseinsky, Matthew J.
        Science (Washington, DC, United States) (2004), 306 (5698), 1012-1015CODEN: SCIEAS; ISSN:0036-8075. (American Association for the Advancement of Science)
        Adsorption and desorption of hydrogen from nanoporous materials, such as activated C, is usually fully reversible. The authors prepd. nanoporous metal-org. framework materials with flexible linkers in which the pore openings, as characterized in the static structures, appear to be too small to allow H2 to pass. The authors observe hysteresis in their adsorption and desorption kinetics above the supercrit. temp. of H2 that reflects the dynamical opening of the windows between pores. This behavior would allow H2 to be adsorbed at high pressures but stored at lower pressures.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2cXptFyjtbc%253D&md5=42cbb6e1b708cd791929d4e89d328f95

        29b
        Hydrogen physisorption in metal-organic porous crystals
        Panella, Barbara; Hirscher, Michael
        Advanced Materials (Weinheim, Germany) (2005), 17 (5), 538-541CODEN: ADVMEW; ISSN:0935-9648. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        Hydrogen adsorption in microporous solid materials may enable H2 to be stored at lower pressures than in compressed-gas tanks, and at higher temps. than for liq. H2. A new class of metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) with a high sp. surface area appears promising for H2 storage. Here, the H2-uptake capacity of MOF-5 over a wide pressure range, at room temp. and at 77 K is investigated. Adsorption of H2 exclusively in the micropores of these metal-org. frameworks is demonstrated.

        29d
        Adsorbent storage of natural gas
        Wegrzyn, J.; Gurevich, M.
        Applied Energy (1996), 55 (2), 71-83CODEN: APENDX; ISSN:0306-2619. (Elsevier)
        The natural-gas vehicle represents a cost-competitive, lower-emission alternative to the gasoline-fueled vehicle. The immediate challenge that confronts the natural-gas vehicle is extension of its driving range. This paper addresses the question of driving range by reviewing the storage technologies for natural gas. Tech. comparisons are made between storage systems for adsorbent, liquefied and compressed natural gas, and ests. are made of the costs assocd. with refueling with compressed and adsorbent natural gas. We discuss carbon adsorbents, vehicle emissions, designs of storage tanks, cost and safety. For storage-tank system design, we advance the concept that carbon adsorbents, when used with conformable-shaped tanks offer a means of increasing onboard fuel storage and, thereby, the driving range of the vehicle. Lower pressures have the advantages of small refueling costs, the availability of conformable tanks and safety. Our suggested soln. to the driving-range problem of a natural-gas vehicle is the use of improved adsorbents in a low pressure (500 psi) conformable-shaped storage tank.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK2sXit12nt7s%253D&md5=987575140b9e78aa7866a1aa1bc8959e

        29e
        Metal-Organic Framework from an Anthracene Derivative Containing Nanoscopic Cages Exhibiting High Methane Uptake
        Ma, Shengqian; Sun, Daofeng; Simmons, Jason M.; Collier, Christopher D.; Yuan, Daqiang; Zhou, Hong-Cai
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2008), 130 (3), 1012-1016CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        A microporous metal-org. framework, PCN-14, based on an anthracene deriv., 5,5'- (9,10-anthracene-diyl)di-isophthalate (H4adip), was synthesized under solvothermal reaction conditions. X-ray single crystal anal. revealed that PCN-14 consists of nanoscopic cages suitable for gas storage. N2-adsorption studies of PCN-14 at 77 K reveal a Langmuir surface area of 2176 m2/g and a pore vol. of 0.87 cm3/g. Methane adsorption studies at 290 K and 35 bar show that PCN-14 exhibits an abs. methane-adsorption capacity of 230 vol./vol., 28% higher than the DOE target (180 vol./vol.) for methane storage.

        29f
        Strategies for hydrogen storage in metal-organic frameworks
        Rowsell, Jesse L. C.; Yaghi, Omar M.
        Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2005), 44 (30), 4670-4679CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        A review. Increased attention is being focused on metal-org. frameworks as candidates for hydrogen storage materials. This is a result of their many favorable attributes, such as high porosity, reproducible and facile syntheses, amenability to scale-up, and chem. modification for targeting desired properties. A discussion of several strategies aimed at improving hydrogen uptake in these materials is presented. These strategies include the optimization of pore size and adsorption energy by linker modification, impregnation, catenation, and the inclusion of open metal sites and lighter metals.
        >> More from SciFinder ®

        29g
        Hydrogen storage in metal-organic frameworks
        Collins, David J.; Zhou, Hong-Cai
        Journal of Materials Chemistry (2007), 17 (30), 3154-3160CODEN: JMACEP; ISSN:0959-9428. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        A review. For any potential hydrogen-storage system, raw uptake capacity must be balanced with the kinetics and thermodn. of uptake and release. Metal-org. frameworks provide unique systems with large overall pore vols. and surface areas, adjustable pore sizes, and tunable framework-adsorbate interaction by ligand functionalization and metal choice. These remarkable materials can potentially fill the niche between other physisorbents such as activated carbon, which have similar uptake at low temps. but low affinity for hydrogen at ambient temp., and chem. sorbents such as hydrides, which have high hydrogen uptakes but undesirable release kinetics and thermodn.
        >> More from SciFinder ®

        An interweaving Cu metal-org. framework possessing high porosity and high H uptake was successfully designed and synthesized. Cu3(TATB)2(H2O)3 (TATB = 4,4',4"-s-triazine-2,4,6-triyl-tribenzoate) was prepd., its structure detd. and its hydrogen adsorption characteristics also detd.

        29i
        Microporous Materials Constructed from the Interpenetrated Coordination Networks. Structures and Methane Adsorption Properties
        Kondo, Mitsuru; Shimamura, Mariko; Noro, Shin-ichiro; Minakoshi, Seika; Asami, Akiko; Seki, Kenji; Kitagawa, Susumu
        Chemistry of Materials (2000), 12 (5), 1288-1299CODEN: CMATEX; ISSN:0897-4756. (American Chemical Society)
        Five new coordination compds. with 4,4'-azopyridine (azpy), [Mn(azpy)(NO3)2(H2O)2]·2EtOH (1·2EtOH), [Co2(azpy)3(NO3)4]·Me2CO·3H2O (2·Me2CO·3H2O), [Co(azpy)2(NCS)2]·0.5EtOH (3·0.5EtOH), [Cd(azpy)2(NO3)2]·(azpy) (4·azpy), and [Cd2(azpy)3(NO3)4]·2Me2CO (5·2Me2CO), were synthesized and structurally characterized. The reaction of Mn(NO3)2·6H2O with azpy in EtOH/acetone affords 1·2EtOH, whose network consists of 1-dimensional chains of [Mn(azpy)(H2O)2]n. The chains are assocd. by H bonding to provide a logcabin-type three-dimensional structure, which creates ∼8 × 8 Å of channels, filled with EtOH mols. The treatment of Co(NO3)2·6H2O and Co(NCS)2·4H2O with azpy produces 2·Me2CO·3H2O and 3·0.5EtOH, resp., which have a brick-wall and a rhombus-type two-dimensional networks. The reaction of Cd(NO3)2·4H2O with azpy affords 4·azpy from the EtOH/H2O media, while the reaction in the EtOH/acetone media provides 5·2Me2CO. 4·Azpy and 5·2Me2CO form a square-grid- and a herringbone-type two-dimensional networks, resp. The two-dimensional sheets of 4·azpy stack without interpenetration, leading to large size of channels, which are filled with free azpy mols. The two-dimensional networks of 2·Me2CO·3H2O, 3·0.5EtOH, and 5·2Me2CO are quadruply, doubly, and triply interpenetrated, resp. Despite the interpenetration, their networks create the microporous channels filled with guest solvent mols. The dried compds. 2, 3, and 5 adsorb methane between 1 and 36 atm at 25°, in which 3 and 5 exhibit Langmuir-type isotherms. The inherent micropore vols. for 3 and 5 are 0.685 and 3.30 mmol/g, resp. XRPD measurements under reduced pressure at 100° reveal that the channel structure of 3 is the most stable in these compds.; the obsd. XRPD pattern is in good agreement with that of the simulated pattern of the single-crystal model. Compds. 2 and 5 also retain the porous structures, however, their pore structures are distorted upon loss of guest included mols.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3cXit1agtbo%253D&md5=bb6783e8d94fa4d01cb7051890954647

        29j
        Different Adsorption Behaviors of Methane and Carbon Dioxide in the Isotypic Nanoporous Metal Terephthalates MIL-53 and MIL-47
        Bourrelly, Sandrine; Llewellyn, Philip L.; Serre, Christian; Millange, Franck; Loiseau, Thierry; Ferey, Gerard
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2005), 127 (39), 13519-13521CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        A distinct step in the isotherm occurs during the adsorption of CO2 on MIL-53 at 304 K. Such behavior is neither obsd. during the adsorption of CH4 on MIL-53 nor during the adsorption on the isostructural MIL-47. This phenomenon seems to be due to a different mechanism than that of previous adsorption steps on MOF samples. It is suggested that a breathing behavior is induced in MIL-53 during CO2 adsorption.

        (k) Dueren, T.; Sarkisov, L.; Yaghi, O. M.; Snurr, R. Q. Langmuir 2004, 20, 2683

        29k
        Design of New Materials for Methane Storage
        Dueren, Tina; Sarkisov, Lev; Yaghi, Omar M.; Snurr, Randall Q.
        Langmuir (2004), 20 (7), 2683-2689CODEN: LANGD5; ISSN:0743-7463. (American Chemical Society)
        One of the strategic goals of the modern automobile manufg. industry is to replace gasoline and diesel with alternative fuels such as natural gas. In this report, we elucidate the desired characteristics of an optimal adsorbent for gas storage. The U.S. Department of Energy has outlined several requirements that adsorbents must fulfill for natural gas to become economically viable, with a key criterion being the amt. adsorbed at 35 bar. We explore the adsorption characteristics of novel metal-org. materials (IRMOFs and mol. squares) and contrast them with the characteristics of two zeolites, MCM-41, and different carbon nanotubes. Using mol. simulations, we uncover the complex interplay of the factors influencing methane adsorption, esp. the surface area, the capacity or free vol., the strength of the energetic interaction, and the pore size distribution. We also explain the extraordinary adsorption properties of IRMOF materials and propose new, not yet synthesized IRMOF structures with adsorption characteristics that are predicted to exceed the best exptl. results to date by up to 36%.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2cXhs1yju70%253D&md5=b58bdcd29d208b0d424b6427980189f4

        (a) Park, K. S.; Ni, Z.; Cote, A. P.; Choi, J. Y.; Huang, R. D.; Uribe-Romo, F. J.; Chae, H. K.; O’Keeffe, M.; Yaghi, O. M. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A 2006, 103, 10186

        30a
        Exceptional chemical and thermal stability of zeolitic imidazolate frameworks
        Park, Kyo Sung; Ni, Zheng; Cote, Adrien P.; Choi, Jae Yong; Huang, Rudan; Uribe-Romo, Fernando J.; Chae, Hee K.; O'Keeffe, Michael; Yaghi, Omar M.
        Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America (2006), 103 (27), 10186-10191CODEN: PNASA6; ISSN:0027-8424. (National Academy of Sciences)
        Twelve zeolitic imidazolate frameworks (ZIFs; termed ZIF-1 to -12) were synthesized as crystals by copolymn. of either Zn(II) (ZIF-1 to -4, -6 to -8, and -10 to -11) or Co(II) (ZIF-9 and -12) with imidazolate-type links. The ZIF crystal structures are based on the nets of seven distinct aluminosilicate zeolites: tetrahedral Si(Al) and the bridging O are replaced with transition metal ion and imidazolate link, resp. One example of mixed-coordination imidazolate of Zn(II) and In(III) (ZIF-5) based on the garnet net is reported. Study of the gas adsorption and thermal and chem. stability of two prototypical members, ZIF-8 and -11, demonstrated their permanent porosity (Langmuir surface area = 1,810 m2/g), high thermal stability (up to 550°), and remarkable chem. resistance to boiling alk. H2O and org. solvents.

        (b) Zhou, W.; Wu, H.; Hartman, M. R.; Yildirim, T. J. Phys. Chem. C 2007, 111, 16131

        30b
        Hydrogen and Methane Adsorption in Metal-Organic Frameworks: A High-Pressure Volumetric Study
        Zhou, Wei; Wu, Hui; Hartman, Michael R.; Yildirim, Taner
        Journal of Physical Chemistry C (2007), 111 (44), 16131-16137CODEN: JPCCCK; ISSN:1932-7447. (American Chemical Society)
        The authors report hydrogen and methane adsorption isotherms in 2 prototypical metal-org. framework compds. (i.e., MOF5 and ZIF8) over a large temp. (30-300 K) and pressure (up to 65 bar) range using a fully computer-controlled Sieverts app. In a volumetric method, a proper choice of real gas equation of state is crit. for obtaining reliable isotherm data. The widely used van der Waals equation of state (EOS) is not adequate to describe H2 and CH4, while the modified Benedict-Webb-Rubin (MBWR) EOS works well, even at very low temps. and high pressures. With the known sample mass and bulk d., the skeleton d. and the specific pore vol. of MOF5 and ZIF8 were also measured. In addn. to excess and abs. adsorption isotherms, the authors also introduce an effective adsorption which compares the amts. of gas adsorbed in a container with and without the adsorbent. At low temps., the maximal excess adsorption capacities of H2 and CH4 in MOF5 are 10.3% and 51.7%, resp., while they are only 4.4% and 22.4% in ZIF8. From the temp.-dependent isotherm data, the isosteric heat of adsorption (Qst) was also estd. The excess Qst's for the initial H2 and CH4 adsorption in MOF5 are ∼4.8 kJ/mol and ∼12.2 kJ/mol, resp. The authors obtained similar Qst's for ZIF8. The authors hope that the detailed isotherm curves reported here over a large temp. and pressure range will be a crit. test for future grand canonical Monte Carlo simulations and force-field models.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2sXhtFWqtbjL&md5=5929450c7b34ee817bcb88a1d1461a5b
        (c) Chen, B. L.; Ma, S. Q.; Hurtado, E. J.; Lobkovsky, E. B.; Zhou, H. C. Inorg. Chem. 2007, 46, 8490

        A triply interpenetrated microporous metal-organic framework for selective sorption of gas molecules
        Chen, Banglin; Ma, Shengqian; Hurtado, Eric J.; Lobkovsky, Emil B.; Zhou, Hong-Cai
        Inorganic Chemistry (2007), 46 (21), 8490-8492CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
        A microporous metal-org. framework Zn(ADC)(4,4'-Bpe)0.5.xG [1; ADC = 4,4'-azobenzenedicarboxylate, 4,4'-Bpe = trans-bis(4-pyridyl)ethylene, G = 2.5DMF.0.5H2O] with a triply interpenetrative primitive cubic net was synthesized and characterized. With pores of ∼3.4 × 3.4 Å, the activated 1a (no solvent) exhibits highly selective sorption behavior toward H2/N2, H2/CO, and CO2/CH4.

        Filling the pores: A zinc-based metal-org. framework (MOF) can be transformed reversibly from an open (a) to a dense (b) configuration. The microporous solid is the 1st example of a MOF that is highly selective in the gas-chromatog. sepn. of alkanes.

        30e
        Exceptional H2 Saturation Uptake in Microporous Metal-Organic Frameworks
        Wong-Foy, Antek G.; Matzger, Adam J.; Yaghi, Omar M.
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2006), 128 (11), 3494-3495CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        Satn. H2 uptake in a series of microporous metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) has been measured at 77 K. Satn. pressures vary between 25 and 80 bar across the series, with MOF-177 showing the highest uptake on a gravimetric basis (7.5 wt %) and IRMOF-20 showing the highest uptake on a volumetric basis at 34 g/L. These results demonstrate that max. H2 storage capacity in MOFs correlates well to surface area, and that feasible volumetric uptakes can be realized even in highly porous materials.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD28XhvVCjsr8%253D&md5=f6d94bff4ebfd39eedeec1e04573a2e4
        (f) Rowsell, J. L. C.; Yaghi, O. M. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2006, 128, 1304
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        30f
        Effects of Functionalization, Catenation, and Variation of the Metal Oxide and Organic Linking Units on the Low-Pressure Hydrogen Adsorption Properties of Metal-Organic Frameworks
        Rowsell, Jesse L. C.; Yaghi, Omar M.
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2006), 128 (4), 1304-1315CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        The dihydrogen adsorption isotherms of eight metal-org. frameworks (MOFs), measured at 77 K up to a pressure of 1 atm, were examd. for correlations with their structural features. All materials display approx. Type I isotherms with no hysteresis, and satn. was not reached for any of the materials under these conditions. Among the six iso-reticular MOFs (IRMOFs) studied, the catenated materials exhibit the largest capacities on a molar basis, up to 9.8 H2 per formula unit. The addn. of functional groups (-Br, -NH2, -C2H4-) to the phenylene links of IRMOF-1 (MOF-5), or their replacement with thieno[3,2-b]thiophene moieties in IRMOF-20, altered the adsorption behavior by a minor amt. despite large variations in the pore vols. of the resulting materials. But replacement of the metal oxide units with those contg. coordinatively unsatd. metal sites resulted in greater H2 uptake. The enhanced affinities of these materials, MOF-74 and HKUST-1, were further demonstrated by calcn. of the isosteric heats of adsorption, which were larger across much of the range of coverage examd., compared to those of representative IRMOFs. Probably under low-loading conditions, the H2 adsorption behavior of MOFs can be improved by imparting larger charge gradients on the metal oxide units and adjusting the link metrics to constrict the pore dimensions; however, a large pore vol. is still a prerequisite feature.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD28XitV2msg%253D%253D&md5=76a0797beec956e59ca2ddf029f5a386
        (g) Dailly, A.; Vajo, J. J.; Ahn, C. C. J. Phys. Chem. B 2006, 110, 1099
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        30g
        Saturation of Hydrogen Sorption in Zn Benzenedicarboxylate and Zn Naphthalenedicarboxylate
        Dailly, Anne; Vajo, John J.; Ahn, Channing C.
        Journal of Physical Chemistry B (2006), 110 (3), 1099-1101CODEN: JPCBFK; ISSN:1520-6106. (American Chemical Society)
        We report excess hydrogen satn. values from high-pressure isotherms of metal org. framework structures taken at 77 K. Zn benzendicarboxylate (IRMOF-1) and Zn naphthalendicarboxylate (IRMOF-8) linker structures show identical satn. values of 137 hydrogen mols. on a per unit cell basis, despite the higher sorption potential of IRMOF-8 of 6.1 kJ/mol over that of IRMOF-1 of 4.1kJ/mol. Charge transfer between linker and vertex, as well as surface area, appear to dominate the sorption behavior, over that of linker length in these two systems.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD28XlsFKn&md5=583b832915589b03e1ce7de5f08fba5b
        (h) Zhao, D.; Yuan, D.; Zhou, H.-C. Energy Environ. Sci. 2008, 1, 222
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        30h
        The current status of hydrogen storage in metal-organic frameworks
        Zhao, Dan; Yuan, Daqiang; Zhou, Hong-Cai
        Energy & Environmental Science (2008), 1 (2), 222-235CODEN: EESNBY; ISSN:1754-5706. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        A review. The theor. and exptl. hydrogen storage studies on metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) have been reviewed. Seven distinct factors influencing hydrogen uptake capacity in MOFs have been classified and discussed. Based on existing studies, some possible future developments have been proposed.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1cXht1amu7%252FM&md5=8cf417a3e457630ab942022a26fc780e
      31. 31

        We replaced the 2-F-4-TBA with 3-F-4-TBA, which is the 3-substituted fluorinated analogue of 4-TBA. The reaction of 3-F-4-TBA with Cu(NO3)2 was resulted into the formation of plate like blue crystals similar to Cu-TBA-2 and Cu-TBA-2F. But in this case, we are unable to grow proper sized crystals for single crystal X-ray diffraction studies after several attempts. The formation of same phase like Cu-TBA-2 and Cu-TBA-2F was confirmed by PXRD studies in the case of Cu-TBA-3F (see Supporting Information, Figure S4).

        There is no corresponding record for this reference.

    • Supporting Information

      Supporting Information

      ARTICLE SECTIONS
      Jump To

      Description of experimental details, including synthetic methods, crystallography, supplementary figures, including TGA, infrared spectroscopy, powder XRD profiles, tables of crystallographic data, CIF files, and anisotropic thermal ellipsoids for MOFs reported in this paper. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.
